Description: Cantrelle was a two-sport star at Teurlings Catholic High (Lafayette, La.), drawing college football interest as a quarterback and leading the Rebels to Louisiana state 4-A baseball championships as a junior and senior. A 40th-round pick by the Yankees in 2017, he became an immediate starter at Louisiana-Lafayette. One of just six NCAA Division I players to total as many as 25 extra-base hits and 25 steals in 2019, he hurt his Draft stock by batting .148 during the four-week college season this spring. A switch-hitter, Cantrelle hits the ball with more authority from the left side of the plate. He has the potential to bat near the top of the batting order with his knack for drawing walks and getting on base, and he also has plus speed and knows how to use it. He has some sneaky pop with 15-homer upside, though he needs to focus less on power and more on making consistent contact. With his quickness and solid arm strength, Cantrelle is capable of playing shortstop at an average big league standard. Teams wanting better defense may prefer him at second base, where he looked good during Cape Cod League play last summer. If he doesn't make enough offensive impact to hold down a regular job, his athleticism and versatility would lend themselves to a utility role.

Name: Justin Fall
Description: Fall was initially slated to head to St. John??s after his high school career in New Jersey, but instead switched to Brookdale Community College in the Garden State. His sophomore year there last year put him on the Draft map, and the Royals took him in the 34th round of the 2019 Draft. Rather than signing, Fall headed across the country to Arizona State and was serving as the Sun Devils?? Sunday starter over the first part of the season. The 6-foot-6 lefty checks off a lot of boxes. He can play catch at 90-92 mph with an effortless delivery. When he reaches back, he can touch 95-96 mph, though he doesn??t get there consistently at this point. He has plus life on his fastball, with arm side run that generates swings and misses. His secondary stuff is more serviceable than standout, with a slider and changeup that could be average offerings. Fall??s command can come and go, sometimes getting into a groove, sometimes losing feel. In the early going in 2020, he??d often scuffle in the first inning, breeze through the next couple, struggle in the fourth, then be strong in the fifth, but have to come out because of a high pitch count. The stuff is there for him to start, but he??ll have to go out and prove he can do it more consistently once he enters pro ball.

Name: R.J. Dabovich
Description: Dabovich might have been a decent Draft prospect coming out of the Colorado high school ranks in 2017, but a knee injury during his senior year at Pueblo West High School knocked him off the radar. Initially headed to Wichita State, Dabovich went the junior college route and enrolled at Central Arizona when the Shockers' pitching coach left the program. The right-hander transferred to Arizona State and worked both as a starter and reliever in his first season with the Sun Devils, finishing things off with a solid performance in the Cape Cod League last summer. The 6-foot-3 hurler has largely lived off two pitches which flash plus. He has plenty of arm strength and can run his fastball up to 97 mph, sitting comfortably in the 93-94 mph range, and he's working on adding more life to it. His breaking ball has hard, three-quarters tilt to it and he'll throw it typically in the low-80s. He will work in a curve on rare occasions and he has a changeup that he wants to try to incorporate more. Pitching solely out of the bullpen before his junior season was shut down, he was proving to be very tough to hit, but also struggled with his command. His fastball-breaking ball combination does tick up in shorter stints and he has the chance to be a very effective big league reliever.

Name: Bryce Bonnin
Description: Scouts were split as to whether Bonnin has a brighter future as a pitcher or shortstop until his senior year of high school in 2017, when he blossomed into a top-three-rounds talent on the mound. Signability concerns dropped him to the 26th round and the Cubs, after which he reached the College World Series with two different schools in two years. He transferred from Arkansas after 2018 because the Razorbacks saw him solely as a reliever, and though he won Texas Tech's super-regional clincher and his lone CWS start last June, he has been inconsistent in the rotation.  Bonnin has a pair of legitimate plus pitches in his fastball and slider, which derive tremendous life from his crossfire delivery. His heater sits at 93-95 mph and tops out at 97 with riding action, while his slider parks in the mid-80s and knifes across the plate. He also has a hard curveball and a changeup, both of which can be average offerings. Bonnin's quality athleticism should help him in his quest to be a starter, but he throws across his body and with effort. He has trouble keeping his mechanics in sync, resulting in below-average control and command. His live arm remains attractive to pro teams, however, even if it's looking increasingly likely that he'll wind up in the bullpen.

Name: Liam Norris
Description: Two years after producing a first-round outfielder in Jordyn Adams, Green Hope High (Cary, N.C.) has another early-round prospect in Norris. While Adams didn't break out until the National High School Invitational during his senior year, Norris has been famous on the showcase circuit for a while. He has the pitches and physicality to go in the first round but won't because he hasn't been able to harness them. Norris' powerful 6-foot-4 frame already produces fastballs that sit at 90-94 mph and peak at 96 with some late life. When he's on, both his upper-70s curveball and low-80s slider grade as at least plus offerings. He's in the early stages of developing a changeup with some sink. More strong than athletic, Norris has difficulty keeping his delivery in sync and staying online to the plate. He has 107 walks in 141 career innings at Green Hope and his command is shakier than his control. He might not go high enough in the Draft to divert him from a North Carolina commitment and his long-term role could be as a reliever.

Name: Carson Seymour
Description: Kansas State has produced just one top-100 pick in Draft history, second-rounder Jack Woolsey back in 1969, but Seymour has the upside to become the second. His wildness limited him to 7 1/3 innings as a Dartmouth freshman in 2018, but he won pitcher of the year honors in the Hamptons League that summer and joined the Wildcats. Transfer rules dictated he sit out the 2019 season, though he intrigued scouts by reaching 96 mph in the Cape Cod League and touching 99 during fall practice. Seymour's physical 6-foot-5 frame produces fastballs that sit at 92-95 when he starts and park at 95-97 in shorter stints, and he uses his size to create downhill plane. He showed the ability to spin a downer curveball on the Cape, though it regressed when he added a mid-80s slider during the fall. His changeup is still a work in progress. While there's some effort in Seymour's delivery, he repeats his simple mechanics fairly well, so he should be able to provide more consistent strikes than he has. If the redshirt sophomore can improve his ability to locate his pitches, he could profile as a starter. He didn't make any progress and his stuff dropped off after a couple of innings during the brief 2020 season, so he may wind up as a reliever.

Name: Ryan Webb
Description: Webb stole the show from Georgia ace and projected top-five-overall pick Emerson Hancock on the first day of the college season, relieving him with 11 strikeouts in five scoreless innings. He won't go in the first round like Hancock or fellow Bulldog Cole Wilcox, but he's Georgia's best southpaw prospect since Alex Wood was a second-rounder in 2012. A team that believes he can transition to starting could take him as early as the third round. Webb's best weapons are his breaking pitches, an upper-70s curveball with depth that ties up both left-handers and right-handers when he locates it, and a low-80s slider that he added this year. He usually operates with a 91-93 mph fastball that reaches 95 and did a better job of holding his velocity for multiple innings during the truncated 2020 season. He also shows some feel for a changeup that could become at least a solid offering if he used it more often. Though he has more than enough pitches to start, Webb has been a full-time reliever since the end of his freshman season. He's still refining his control and command, and he needs to do a better job of locating his fastball because he can't just blow it by hitters. He has an upright delivery and missed six weeks in 2019 with a sore arm, so scouts aren't totally sold that he can handle a starter's workload.

Name: Luke Waddell
Description: A 32nd-round pick as a sophomore a year ago, Waddell turned down the D-backs and spent the summer as the first Georgia Tech player on the U.S. collegiate national team since Derek Dietrich in 2008. The primary leadoff hitter on Team USA, he has the attributes to serve in that role in pro ball as well. He has one of the best floors among college infielders, with a high likelihood of serving at least a utility role and a chance to become a regular. Waddell focuses on making contact with a measured left-handed swing. That approach doesn't yield much in the way of power, but he repeatedly produces line drives to all fields and enhances his on-base ability by controlling the count. A plus runner who was a star running back at Loveland (Ohio) High, he has the quickness and know-how to steal bases. After dividing his time between three infield positions as a freshman, Waddell took over as the Yellow Jackets' shortstop early in his sophomore season. An average defender with solid arm strength at shortstop, he profiles as a better defender at second base. He's also capable of playing third base but doesn't fit the offensive profile there.

Name: Trei Cruz
Description: Cruz may have the most extensive big league pedigree in this year's Draft, as his father Jose, grandfather Jose and great-uncles Hector and Tommy all played in the Majors. His uncle Enrique started at second base for the 2003 College World Series champions at Rice, where Trei has spent the last three seasons. Selected in the 35th round out of high school by the Astros in 2017 and in the 37th round as a sophomore-eligible by the Nationals in 2019, he should fit in the first five rounds after improving several aspects of his game. A switch-hitter, Cruz has toned down his approach after selling out for home runs in the past. He has modified a big leg kick he used from the left side of the plate and displayed better strike-zone discipline during the truncated 2020 season. Scouts see him as a hit-over-power guy who could provide 15 homers on an annual basis. Cruz posted below-average running times in the past but now flashes average speed, especially once he gets going, and shows aggressiveness and savvy on the bases. His average arm and fringy range don't lend themselves to sticking at shortstop, though he may get a chance to play there for a while in pro ball after displaying more quickness this spring. His best fit is at second base, where he played well as a freshman.

Name: Tyler Keenan
Description: Keenan went off in Mississippi's shortened 17-game schedule, homering seven times and ranking second in NCAA Division I with 33 RBIs. One of the better lefty sluggers in the college crop, he topped the Rebels with 15 homers last season and finished second at the College Home Run Derby.  The 6-foot-4, 240-pound Keenan is all about power, using his strength and bat speed to launch balls with topspin. There's some concern as to how well his uppercut swing will play against pro pitching, but he manages the strike zone well and uses the entire field. He makes consistent contact, getting to his pop while producing high exit velocities. A well-below-average runner, Keenan offers no value on the bases and doesn't cover much ground at third base. He has reliable hands and solid arm strength, as well as determination to stay at the hot corner, but his lack of range and ability to make throws on the run likely will land him at first base in pro ball. Former Rebel Thomas Dillard had a similar offensive profile and more athleticism when the Brewers selected him in the fifth round last year, and Keenan should go in roughly the same area.

Name: Trenton Denholm
Description: UC Irvine has produced a fair amount of Draft talent over the years, led by 2017 first-round pick Keston Hiura. Denholm, a smaller pitchability right-hander who began the year as the Anteaters?? ace, won??t do as well as the Brewers?? second baseman, but has the chance to land somewhere in the top four or five rounds. Denholm has a reputation for being one of the best college strike-throwers in the country. He doesn??t have huge stuff, but he can command all three pitches well and never gives in to hitters. He??ll throw his fastball in the 90-93 mph range and he backs it up with a plus changeup, his best offering that keeps hitters off-balance. His 75-77 mph curveball is improving and he started tinkering with a slider. Not only does Denholm throw strikes at will with all three, he??s done it against good competition, posting a 0.00 ERA in 28 2/3 Cape Cod League innings over two summers. He had taken over as Irvine??s Friday night starter from Andre Pallante, who was a fourth-round pick in 2019, and has the chance to go in the same neck of the woods come Draft time.

Name: Jackson Leath
Description: Leath showcased one of the better arms in the Texas junior college ranks last spring at Blinn, but his commitment to Tennessee left him undrafted. The Volunteers used him as a starter and long reliever this year, and he won all four of his extended outings while striking out 29 in 18 2/3 innings. Though his future role has yet to be determined, he should fit in the first three to five rounds of the Draft. During the shortened 2020 season, Leath showed the ability to maintain a 92-95 mph fastball with sink for four or five innings at a time, topping out at 97. He also misses bats with a mid-80s slider/cutter that's effective against both left-handers and right-handers. He rounds out his repertoire with a hard curveball and a changeup that shows the potential to become an average offering. Leath isn't especially tall but he's strong and physical, which bodes well for his durability. He has no problems throwing strikes, so he can project as a four-pitch starter or as a multi-inning reliever who focuses on his fastball and slider. The team that drafts him likely will give him the opportunity to develop in the rotation.

Name: Trevor Hauver
Description: Arizona State was an easy stop on the early scouting trail in 2020. Not only could many teams?? scouts check in with parent clubs during Spring Training, but there were many Sun Devils worth checking out. At the top of that list, of course, is Spencer Torkelson, but after a slow start, Hauver was starting to show his bat deserved plenty of attention on its own. After scuffling a bit as a freshman, Hauver began to show what he??s capable of doing as a sophomore, hitting .339/.433/.574, largely as the Sun Devils?? leadoff hitter. A move to the three-hole behind Torkelson messed him up initially, but he was starting to heat up and show once again he can drive the ball and he can draw walks from the left side of the plate. He has the chance to hit for both average and power at the next level with a solid overall approach. His bat is going to have to play because it??s a bit unclear where he plays defensively. A shortstop in high school, Hauver played left field at ASU because there were better options on the dirt on the roster. He believes he can play the infield, and if that??s the case, second base would be the best bet given his limited range. Some see a Daniel Murphy type in the future, one who maybe plays second, left, even some first base, with his bat carrying him up the ladder.

Name: Yohandy Morales
Description: Back in 2001, the Yankees signed Cuban defector Andy Morales to a four-year deal, only to cut ties with the infielder, reportedly because he had lied about his age. Nearly two decades later, his son Yohandy has the chance to enter pro ball as one of the top high school infielders from Florida with some offensive upside. Big and physical, Morales has the chance to hit, and with power, in the future. He has a knack for barreling up the baseball, though he can be too much of a guess hitter and there are a lot of moving parts to his swing. That said, there is a lot of raw pop for the right-handed hitter to tap into if he can smooth some things out mechanically and refine his overall approach. Fairly physically mature, Morales played shortstop in high school, but nearly everyone sees a move to his father??s old position at the hot corner. He does have a strong arm, and continued work on his footwork and hands should make him more than capable at third. Teams who think his bat will profile well at the infield corner will take the chance at signing him away from his University of Miami commitment.

Name: Coby Mayo
Description: Stoneman Douglas High School in Florida has produced some serious talent over the years, starting with Cubs first baseman Anthony Rizzo and continuing with A??s left-hander Jesus Luzardo and Rockies third-base prospect Colton Welker. Mayo also plays the hot corner, with the kind of power potential that many teams covet. There are no questions about Mayo??s raw power from the right side of the plate. He can flat-out crush the ball, using his strong 6-foot-5 frame to his advantage. The concerns crop up regarding whether he??ll hit enough to get to that power on a consistent basis. There??s swing and miss to his game and while he??ll show the ability to drive the ball to the opposite field in batting practice, he can get very pull-happy in games. Not everyone is convinced Mayo can stick at third as well. While he does have a well above-average arm, his feet and hands are just OK, which might mean a move to first base or maybe to left field. His strong arm, power and physicality might remind some of Austin Riley and the team that tries to sign him away from his commitment to Florida will believe that??s who he can become.

Name: Tyler Brown
Description: Brown already has overcome more adversity than most players will face, losing his mother to cancer when he was 13, blowing out his elbow and having Tommy John surgery as a high school sophomore, and fathering a daughter born with Down syndrome and life-threatening heart defects when he was a Vanderbilt freshman. His toughness translates to the mound, where he set a school record with 17 saves in 2019, including three in Omaha as the Commodores won their second national championship. He wasn't as sharp in the shortened 2020 season but still should be one of the first relievers drafted. Brown usually attacks hitters with a 91-94 mph fastball with running action that misses bats up in the strike zone, topping out at 96, and an 83-86 mph slider. Both pitches were more solid than plus this spring but have shown better in the past. He also mixes in a mid-70s curveball with more depth than power to give batters a different look, and he can throw them off balance with a decent low-80s changeup. As with his stuff, Brown's control and command were a tick down this year but he usually pounds the zone. With his four pitches, strike-throwing ability and a strong 6-foot-4 build, some scouts think he has the ingredients to start and could get the opportunity to do so in pro ball. Other evaluators believe his delivery and mentality are better suited for late-inning relief.

Name: Holden Powell
Description: As a freshman, Powell took over as UCLA??s closer and held on to the job until the 2020 season was ended prematurely. He racked up 26 saves, second in school history behind only David Berg, and was quickly becoming one of the best relief pitching options in the Draft class this spring, with a 20/2 K/BB ratio while allowing just three hits and no runs over 9 1/3 innings in eight appearances. Powell isn??t one of those college relievers you wonder about whether he could start at the next level. The nation??s Stopper of the Year as a sophomore, the 6-foot right-hander is bullpen only, but the type who could move quickly. He typically sits in the low 90s with his fastball and is regularly up to 96 mph. It??s his slider, though, that??s the real separator. It??s a filthy out pitch that gets a ton of swings and misses, a plus pitch for sure. Powell does have a changeup, but it??s that electric fastball-slider combination that has peaked scouts?? interest. With a loud delivery, he??s had trouble with command, but was finding the strike zone more consistently this spring and throws enough strikes to profile well in the back of a bullpen, a role he relishes, with the makeup to close games at the next level.

Name: Hunter Barnhart
Description: Finding multisport athletes who want to play baseball at the next level has long been a challenge for scouts. This year??s Draft offers several players who showed their ability on the gridiron as quarterbacks as well as the baseball field, starting with top 100 players like Cade Horton in Oklahoma and Nolan McLean in North Carolina. Barnhart, who was the MVP of his league as St. Joseph??s QB, had his name jumping up Draft boards and moving closer to those two thanks to a quick start this spring. There were two things that jumped out in Barnhart??s performances this spring that gave him some helium. The first was more velocity with his fastball, up to 96 mph at times. The other was his curve, a true plus breaking ball thrown 77-80 mph that he can really spin. His changeup is behind the other two and he hasn??t thrown it much, but he throws the 81-84 mph offspeed pitch with good arm speed and it has the chance to develop into an average offering in the future. Though his inexperience as a pitcher shows at times in terms of his approach and mechanics, Barnhart throws a lot of strikes and it??s easy to believe that the big, strong, athletic right-hander will have solid command in the future. There was an up arrow next to his name when things shut down and thought of him being committed to pitching only could have teams willing to take the Arizona State commit in the top five rounds.

Name: Alec Burleson
Description: East Carolina produced a pair of top-five-round picks for the first time ever in 2019, with left-hander Jake Agnos going in the fourth round to the Yankees and outfielder Bryant Packard in the fifth to the Tigers. It should happen again in 2020 with righty Gavin Williams and Burleson. Though Burleson is one of the top two-way performers in college baseball and pulled double duty for the U.S. collegiate national team last summer, clubs consider him a much better prospect as a hitter than as a pitcher. Burleson has a pretty left-handed swing and seems to make line-drive contact almost at will. Most of his pop has gone to the gaps rather than over the fence in college, leading to questions about his home run ceiling. Some evaluators see him as a hit-over-power guy who will max out at 15 homers, while others envision his strength, bat speed and solid raw pop translating into 20 or more on an annual basis. Though Burleson is a better athlete than he gets credit for, he still lacks speed and range and will need to hit for power to become a big league regular. He shows good hands and plays solid defense at first base but doesn't cover enough ground to man the outfield corners in pro ball after seeing time there with the Pirates. On the mound, he's a finesse lefty who backs up an 87-90 mph fastball with an effective slider and changeup.

Name: Chase Hampton
Description: The second tier of Texas high school pitchers includes several Texas Tech recruits, with Hampton ranking as the best of a group that also includes right-handers Marco Raya (United South High, Laredo) and Levi Wells (LaPorte High). As a junior, Hampton led Kilgore to the state 4-A semifinals. He showed improved stuff this spring and looked like a third- or fourth-rounder on his best days. Hampton can show a 91-93 mph fastball that tops out at 95 with four-seam, riding action, and there also are games when he works more at 88-91. His curveball similarly fluctuates in quality, ranging from a near-plus offering with depth to a looser version. His changeup displays some fade and should improve as he uses it more often.  Hampton's arm works fine and he has cleaned up his three-quarters delivery some since last summer, so he should throw enough strikes to start. Like many high school pitchers, his control is more advanced than his command and he'll have to learn to locate his pitches better at the next level. If he doesn't turn pro, scouts believe he can contribute immediately at Texas Tech.

Name: Nick Griffin
Description: Two Arkansas high school pitchers thrust themselves into top-five-rounds consideration at the Future Stars Series at Fenway Park last September. Watson Chapel (Pine Bluff) right-hander Markevian Hence will go earlier in the Draft because he has more present stuff and he's more signable, though Griffin has the advantages of being left-handed and more projectable. Both Arkansas recruits won??t turn 18 until after they graduate this spring, making them more appealing to clubs that put more emphasis on age. Griffin has added 20 pounds of muscle since last summer and still has more room to add strength to his lanky 6-foot-4 frame. He already works at 89-92 mph and tops out at 94 with his fastball, and he should pick up more velocity as he matures physically. He shows some feel for spinning a curveball with good depth, and he also can get some swings and misses with his slider. Griffin's arm action is a bit long but he's making strides with his relatively easy delivery. He should develop better feel for a changeup when he uses it more at the next level and his athleticism should translate into at least average control and command. He also shows some promise as a hitter and could fit the right-field profile, though teams clearly prefer him on the mound.

Name: Nick Yorke
Description: Archbishop Mitty High School in San Jose, Calif., has produced three big leaguers in the history of the Draft: Outfielders Mike Vail, who first came up with the Mets in 1975, and Mitch Haniger, who went on to Cal Poly before being drafted by the Brewers in 2012, as well as right-hander Trevor Hildenberger, who wasn??t drafted out of high school, but was drafted out of Cal in 2014. Yorke isn??t projected to go as early as Haniger did after his college career (No. 38 overall), but it??s a strong possibility his bat gets him off the board way earlier than either Vail (17th round of June 1970 Draft) or Haniger (31st round, 2009). Scouts believe Yorke has a real chance to swing the bat, with perhaps even plus hit potential from the right side of the plate. He??s a natural hitter with a pure swing and an advanced approach at the plate and there??s enough power potential in there to believe he could eventually be a run-producing type of player.  The questions about Yorke pop up concerning his future defensive home. He??s played shortstop in high school, and might have the range, hands and instincts to stay there, but he had shoulder surgery and has anchors in his shoulder causing him to DH for all of his junior year in 2019. He was back on the dirt this spring, but what had been solid average arm strength had not yet returned. Still, he could profile very well as an offensive-minded second baseman with a bat that could be worth luring away from his commitment to the University of Arizona.

Name: Max Rajcic
Description: Playing for Southern California high school powerhouse Orange Lutheran High School, Rajcic contributed to three straight National High School Invitational titles, one as a hitter as a freshman, then the next two as a two-way star. He also played for Team USA??s 18-and-under team in international competition for two years, so he??s extremely well known by the scouting industry. There isn??t much projection left with the undersized right-hander, but there??s a lot of now stuff to like about Rajcic. He has the chance to have three average to above-average offerings in the future. His fastball sits 92-93 mph consistently, thrown with a lot of sink and commanded well, and he maintains his velocity deep into starts. He backs it up with a high-spin breaking ball, a slider that flashes plus. His changeup is a touch behind, but he shows enough feel for it to easily see an at least average offspeed offering. Rajcic has always thrown a lot of strikes and as a guy who hit in the middle of OLU??s lineup, his athleticism plays very well on the mound. He clearly loves the big stage and is super competitive, something teams will certainly take into account when deciding if they want to try to sign him away from his commitment to UCLA.

Name: Ty Floyd
Description: The top pitcher in Louisiana State's recruiting class, Floyd is one of the more athletic pitchers in the 2020 Draft but is also very much a work in progress. Scouts thought he had a chance to go in the first two rounds entering the year, though continued inconsistency during the brief high school season may make it difficult to take him high enough to divert him from Baton Rouge. Floyd has a quick arm that generates 90-95 mph fastballs, getting swings and misses up in the strike zone with riding action. He'll show glimpses of a solid curveball but it's not reliable yet, often degenerating into more of a slurve. He hasn't had much need for a changeup to this point, so it lags behind his other offerings. Floyd's delivery features some effort and recoil that detract from his fastball command. In order to pay him enough to lure him away from LSU, a club will have to bank that his athleticism will allow him to clean up his mechanics and polish his repertoire. It's quite possible that he winds up attending college and develops into one of the top arms in the 2023 Draft.

Name: Jesse Franklin
Description: Washington's top high school prospect in 2017, Franklin dropped to the Mariners in the 37th round because of his steadfast commitment to Michigan. He starred as a freshman and while his numbers declined as a sophomore as he got more power-happy, he helped the Wolverines to a shocking second-place finish at the 2019 College World Series. Scouts were curious as to which version would show up in 2020, but he broke his collarbone in a skiing accident and never took the field before the shortened season ended. Franklin's strength gives him solid to plus raw power and he's at his best when he lets it come naturally. He did a better job of that in 2018 compared to last year, when he improved at controlling the strike zone but didn't make as much quality contact while his left-handed stroke got more uphill. He has hit for average but with only modest power in the wood-bat Cape Cod League, so his offensive projection remains a bit of a puzzle. Franklin also possesses solid speed but doesn't always play that fast. He hasn't shown much basestealing prowess and displays shaky reads and routes at times in center field. He has fringy arm strength, so if he can't stay up the middle he'll have to play left field.

Name: Timmy Manning
Description: There are high school arms who are all about arm strength, velocity and ceiling. Then there are those who present themselves more like college arms, who really know how to pitch but might not currently have wow, jump-off-the-page kind of stuff. Manning fits into the latter category as a left-hander who showed an ability to mix pitches and keep hitters off-balance over the summer, particularly during his time at Major League Baseball's PDP League. Manning has the chance to have a very good three-pitch mix at his disposal. His best pitch is his curveball, thrown with excellent spin, depth and finish. He typically throws it in the mid-70s and he commands it better than his fastball, with a chance for it to be a true out pitch for the left-hander. His fastball is fringe-to-average, and he runs it up to 91 mph. Manning can spot it fairly well and he does have the chance to add some strength and perhaps a few ticks to it in the future. He has good feel for his changeup, and it could be a second plus pitch in time, but he goes to his curve to get right-handed hitters out currently. Manning typically has a delivery that works very well, allowing him to find the strike zone consistently. Any teams interested in obtaining his feel for pitching, even without any velocity gains this spring, will have to contend with his commitment to the University of Florida.

Name: Tekoah Roby
Description: Florida is a hotbed for Draft talent every year, but the Panhandle hasn??t always been as accessible. Roby had impressed some scouts over the summer and backed it up at the start of the spring, though the early end of the season kept him from being as seen as much as he would??ve been under normal circumstances, when scouts would??ve headed to Pensacola as word of Roby??s stuff spread. Roby has the makings of a very solid three-pitch mix, coming from a solid frame, loose delivery, long arms and loose wrist action that allows for good movement on his pitches. He??ll throw his fastball in the 89-94 mph range, with excellent sinking life. He complements it with a 74-78 mph downer-breaking curveball, a pitch that??s at least above-average in the future. He does have a changeup, but he needs to work on developing it to catch it up with his fastball-curve combination. The right-hander who is committed to Troy University tends to be around the strike zone, but needs to improve his overall control and command. While he??s not the biggest guy in the world, there is some projection here, with teams considering him in the top few rounds seeing a potential No. 4 type starter in the future.

Name: Jack Leftwich
Description: Leftwich moved from his high school to focus on baseball at TNXL Academy while finishing his academics online. While the Tigers took him in the 39th round of the 2017 Draft, everyone knew he was headed to join the University of Florida pitching staff. He's been a part of it for two years, being a weekend starter with Tommy Mace as a sophomore and then pitching well in the Cape Cod League. The big and strong right-hander is still more thrower than pitcher, with a power repertoire that does give him the chance to start. He has better pure stuff than Mace, with an explosive fastball that hits 96 mph regularly and sits around 94 mph consistently. He throws his low-80s slider with late break and depth, a real hard, downer power slider. He throws his changeup with about the same velocity as his slider and he throws it with good arm speed. While Leftwich is generally around the strike zone, often attacking up in the zone, he doesn't command the ball well within it consistently. He'll get every chance to start given his repertoire and his ability to maintain velocity deep into starts, traits that should get him a lot of looks as the Draft approaches.

Name: Kale Emshoff
Description: Emshoff hit .253 with four homers in his first two seasons at Arkansas-Little Rock before blowing out his elbow during the Trojans' scout day in the fall of 2018. After missing all of 2019 following Tommy John surgery, he returned to bat .417 and homer seven times in 17 games this spring, going deep in five of his last seven contests before the season ended. The redshirt junior has a chance to become the highest pick in school history, surpassing 2003 fourth-rounder Rick Guarno. Emshoff first hinted at his power by winning the MINK League home run derby after his freshman season. The strength and leverage in his 6-foot-2, 228-pound frame gives him plus raw pop that he's tapping into more often as he improves his plate discipline. He could provide enough offense to possibly profile at an infield corner if he doesn't stick behind the plate. With his fringy to average receiving skills, Emshoff should be able to remain at catcher. He hasn't bounced all the way back from elbow reconstruction but has displayed solid arm strength in the past. He's a bottom-of-the-scale runner but moves well enough behind the dish and has aptitude for blocking balls.

Name: Shane Drohan
Description: Back in 2017, Drohan was a high school lefty in Florida with some upside and some helium. A top 100 prospect on MLB Pipeline??s Draft list, the son of former Minor League right-hander Bill Drohan was a two-sport standout who ended up going to Florida State rather than sign with the Phillies, who took him in the 23rd round of the Draft that June. After spending most of his sophomore year as a starter, he was establishing himself as a mainstay in the Seminoles?? weekend rotation this spring. A successful high school quarterback before turning his complete focus to baseball, Drohan is still learning how to pitch, meaning there??s still ceiling to reach. He??ll touch 95 mph with his fastball at times and sits 92-93 consistently. He hides the ball well and that deception leads to a lot of swings and misses on the pitch. He has the chance to have an above-average curveball, with good three-quarter break to it and his changeup continues to improve. Drohan??s command comes and goes, but because of his athleticsm, there??s confidence from many scouts that he??ll be able to repeat his delivery and throw more consistent strikes. There??s still a lot to dream on here, giving the southpaw more upside than the typical college pitcher.

Name: Colby Halter
Description: To date, the best hitter to come out of Bishop Kenney High School in Jacksonville, Fla., has been Ben Gamel, a 10th-round pick in 2010 now with the Brewers, though Kevin Witt was a first-rounder taken by the Blue Jays back in 1994. Halter likely won??t go as early as Witt did, but after a summer that saw him hit .333 in PDP League play and then .419 for Team USA in international competition, his bat was certainly on people??s radars, though he did get off to a slower start this spring. Halter is more of the type who gets called a real ???baseball player?? rather than having any eye-popping tools. His ability to hit does stand out more than anything else and the left-handed hitter showed an ability over the summer to make consistent hard contact against good competition. He??s more extra-base authority than home run pop right now, but the knack for barreling up the ball is hard to ignore. A shortstop in high school, most feel Halter will have to move positions. He played all over the infield for Team USA and because he might not have the power to profile at third, his best chance at being an every day player at one spot might be second. He reminds some in the area of Tyler Callihan, who got an over-slot bonus from the Reds to sign last year. The same might need to happen to keep Halter from heading to the University of Florida.

Name: Sammy Infante
Description: Monsignor Edward Pace High School in Miami has produced a ton of professional talent, more notably on the mound with big leaguers like Gio Gonzalez and Alex Fernandez. The most recent high Draft pick was shortstop Jeter Downs, taken 32nd overall by the Reds and now a highly regarded prospect in the Red Sox's system. Infante, who stood out at events like the East Coast Pro Showcase last summer, hopes to follow in Downs?? footsteps as a middle infielder from the school to the pro game, though he isn??t expected to go quite as early. Infante has shown glimpses of being able to do a lot of different things well on the baseball field, even if he doesn??t have a true wow tool. Over the summer, he showed an ability to make hard contact and drive the ball. There have been contact issues in the past, but he was making adjustments and there??s some raw power to tap into there. Infante is an average runner, and the jury is still out as to whether he can stay at shortstop. Those who believe he can point to his strong arm and decent actions. Others feel he lacks the quickness to stay there and might be better suited at second or third, where there would be more pressure on the power to show up. And there are some who see a future Maikel Franco type of player. A team that believes his tools will translate to the pro game is likely to take him early enough to sign him away from his Miami commitment.

Name: Tyler McDonough
Description: McDonough caught in high school but found projected 2020 first-rounder Patrick Bailey behind the plate when he got to North Carolina State, so he played center field as a freshman last spring. He split time between center and second base this year, showing the ability to handle both positions while extending his streak of college games without ever making an error to 78. A product of Moeller High (Cincinnati), which has spawned 14 big leaguers and a pair of Hall of Famers in Ken Griffey Jr. and Barry Larkin, he's eligible for the 2020 Draft because he's already 21. A switch-hitter, McDonough makes quality contact and controls the strike zone from both sides of the plate. While his on-base skills stand out more than his power, he can drive the ball on occasion and did so more consistently as a sophomore. He has solid speed and the instincts to make the most of it on the bases. McDonough's quickness also translates into range in the field. He takes good routes in center field, where he's a solid defender with arm strength to match, and offers similar upside at second base once he gets more experience there. One scout described him as a grinder in the mold of Adam Eaton.

Name: Grant Richardson
Description: Richardson earned a starting job at Indiana a month into his 2019 freshman season, which was highlighted by a three-homer game against Maryland. He played as well as any sophomore in college baseball this spring, leading the Big Ten Conference with five homers in 14 games while batting .424/.453/.797. Draft-eligible because he'll turn 21 in mid-July, he could sneak into the first five rounds if he's signable. After adding strength last offseason, Richardson is hitting the ball harder and now shows solid raw power from the left side of the plate. He does come with some swing-and-miss concerns because he struck out in 30 percent of his plate appearances in his first two years with the Hoosiers, but there are no red flags with his swing. If he can tone down his aggressive approach, he could do more consistent damage. Richardson ran a 6.54-second 60-yard dash at a Great Lakes League workout last summer, though his speed plays closer to solid on the bases and in center field. He spent most of his freshman season in right field before taking over for Pirates 2019 second-rounder Matt Gorski in center this spring. He has a chance to stay there in pro ball but may fit better on a corner, and he has enough arm strength to handle right field.

Name: Kevin Abel
Description: Abel was a solid high school prospect in the San Diego area back in 2017, one who was much more about pitchability and command than pure stuff. His strong commitment to Oregon State led to him not getting selected until the 35th round that June. Scouts were getting excited at the chance to draft him again in 2020, especially after a strong freshman year that culminated in a huge performance in the College World Series clinching game, but he needed Tommy John surgery as a sophomore, leaving a big question mark next to his name. When healthy, Abel is still very much about his advanced feel for pitching. His fastball was in the 90-93 mph range, sitting 90-91, and he commanded it to both sides of the plate very well. He??s willing to throw his curveball, close to a 12-to-6 breaking ball with deep late action to it, at any point in the count. His changeup is a plus offering as well and he??s long pitched like a veteran in terms of not giving in to hitters and sticking to a gameplan. The hope was that Abel would have returned at some point in 2020, but that hadn??t happened at the time of the shut down. So any team contemplating trying to sign Abel away from staying at Oregon State to prove he??s healthy in 2021 will have to do so based almost entirely on his freshman year in 2018.

Name: Hugh Fisher
Description: Fisher exhibited top-five-rounds talent as a Tennessee high schooler in 2017, but his Vanderbilt commitment rendered him unsignable and he went undrafted. He spent his first two college seasons in the bullpen and contributed to the Commodores' 2019 national title, then blew out his elbow and had Tommy John surgery last fall. He might have fit in the top three rounds had he been healthy and pitched well this spring, and while that didn't happen, he has enough track record that he still could get picked early enough to sign him. Fisher had plenty of projection in his 6-foot-5 frame when he arrived in Nashville, and his fastball has gained velocity as he has gotten stronger. He went from working at 88-91 mph as a high school senior to operating at 94-96 in shorter stints as a college sophomore. He also has added some power to his breaking ball, which has become a low-80s slider, but hasn't used his changeup much as a reliever. Employing a low three-quarters arm slot with some crossfire in his delivery, Fisher creates tough angle for left-handers and deception but sometimes has trouble keeping his long limbs in sync. That leads to inconsistencies with his control, which leads more scouts to project him strictly as a reliever. It's possible that the team that selects him will give him a chance to start, which he never got on loaded Vanderbilt pitching staffs.

Name: Dalton Fowler
Description: After displaying a low-80s fastball as a Tennessee high school junior in 2017 and a mid-80s heater as a senior, Fowler popped up on scouting radars when he jumped into the low 90s last spring as a Northwest Mississippi CC freshman. Inconsistency left a large gap between his present and his projection, so he wound up dropping to the Mets in the 27th round amid signability concerns. He initially planned to transfer to Mississippi for 2020, but returned to the Rangers to remain Draft-eligible. Fowler led Division II junior college pitchers in strikeout rate (18.5 per nine innings) this spring while usually sitting at 90-91 mph and touching 93 with sink on his fastball. He has some feel for spinning the ball, flashing a mid-70s curveball with good depth but also struggling at times to stay on top of his breaker. He also shows some aptitude with his changeup, giving him a potential three-pitch mix. Though Fowler did a better job of throwing strikes during the shortened 2020 season, his control and command still need a lot of work. He has cleaned up his low three-quarters delivery and is doing a better job of holding his velocity, which dipped as low as 86 mph at times a year ago. He did get crosschecked some despite making only four starts, and he'll head to Oklahoma if he doesn't turn pro this summer.

Name: T.J. Nichols
Description: Before last summer, Nichols was a relatively unknown two-way player from the Northern California high school ranks. Then he took the mound at the Area Code Games in August and opened a ton of eyes as an intriguing, albeit raw, right-hander with arm strength who was high on follow lists at the start of the spring. He was a little inconsistent out of the gate before the season ended. Athletic and wiry, Nichols has pitched and played the infield for his high school team and has the chance to continue to do both should he go on to college. He??s more of a thrower than a pitcher right now, but he??s shown the ability to get his fastball up to 96 mph and added strength should help him find velocity more consistently. He couples the fastball with a very effective short slider with good action to it, a breaking ball that could be a plus pitch in time. He??s struggled to find feel for a changeup, so it??s not been much of a factor for him. Because of that lack of a third pitch, as well as some command and delivery issues, there is some reliever risk with Nichols. But there??s also a ton of upside thanks to his athleticism and projectable frame. Originally committed to Sacramento State, he switched to Arizona, where he could play on the left side of the infield and pitch for the Wildcats if the Draft doesn??t work out.

Name: Jason Savacool
Description: Savacool has the chance to be the third right-handed pitcher from Baker High School in the upstate New York town of Baldwinsville to be drafted, following Jason Grilli (a 24th-rounder in 1994, who went on to Seton Hall University, and was a first-round selection in 1997), and Royals 2014 second-rounder Scott Blewett, who reached Triple-A in 2019. Savacool had a strong summer showcase circuit performance and pitched well for USA Baseball??s 18U National Team, leaving scouts excited to see him this spring, something that didn??t happen because of the coronavirus pandemic. While Savacool isn??t the typical tall and projectable high school right-hander, he does have an athletic build and wide shoulders that allow him to have present strength and the potential for more. He also has a free and easy arm action that delivers a potential four-pitch mix and a more advanced feel for pitching that one might expect from a cold-weather prepster. He??ll throw his fastball up to 94 mph, sitting in the 92-93 range consistently. He complements his heater not only with a solid upper-70s slider, but also with a circle change as well as a split-fingered changeup with good action to it. Savacool goes right after hitters with a very good game plan, one that was on display at top events like the PDP League and East Coast Professional Showcase. He wasn??t able to raise his stock anymore this spring, so scouts will have to rely completely on those summer performances to evaluate the Maryland recruit.

Name: Jake Smith
School: State College of Florida Manatee - Sarasota
Description: A standout high school pitcher in North Carolina as the 2018 Draft approached, Smith was initially committed to UNC-Wilmington, but he opted to head to Chipola Junior College rather than go the four-year school route or sign with the Phillies, who had drafted him in the 21st round. He went from there to the State Junior College of Florida and had gotten off to a very good start in the Manatees?? rotation this spring before the season was shut down. The 6-foot-5 right-hander has a big arm that has shown the ability to miss a lot of bats, as Smith struck out better than 13 per nine innings this spring. He does it mostly with a fastball-slider combination that gets on hitters in a hurry. He??s up to 96 mph, touching 97 mph when he was out of the bullpen at Chipola with his fastball. His slider will flash above average, but it??s not as consistent as his heater, and while he does have a changeup, it??s far behind the other two offerings. Deception in his delivery keeps hitters from getting good looks, and Smith was doing a nice job repeating his delivery and throwing strikes over his 40 innings of work this spring. He might best be suited for a relief role, where the fastball-slider combination would play up, but teams might be willing to send him out as a starter and see if he can develop enough of a third pitch to stick in a rotation.

Name: Grayson Hitt
Description: Hitt is the best prospect to come out of Houston High (Germantown, Tenn.) since 2002 first-rounder Matt Cain and 2003 second-rounder Stuart Pomeranz, both of whom reached the big leagues. He's also a star wide receiver who caught 54 passes for 1,101 yards and 18 touchdowns as Houston went to the state 6-A semifinals last fall. His projectability stands out more than his present stuff and he didn't get much of a chance to pitch this spring, which makes it more likely that he follows through on his college commitment to Alabama. Hitt can run his fastball up to 93 mph and usually deals at 88-91, and he could sit in the mid-90s once he fills out his 6-foot-3 frame. He backs it up with a curveball that features good depth and should become at least a solid offering once he adds more power. He also shows some feel for a changeup that will become more reliable as he uses it more often. With his size and a high three-quarters arm angle, Hitt creates downhill plane on his pitches. The combination of his athleticism and his easy delivery allows him to throw strikes, though he'll need to continue refining his command. If he joins the Crimson Tide, he could blossom into an early-round pick in 2023.

Name: Jacob Misiorowski
Description: With coronavirus shutting down sports across the country, several projectable high school pitchers never got the chance to show scouts what they could do this spring, making it nearly impossible to invest enough in them to divert them from college. A prime example is Misiorowski, who was hampered by a hamstring injury last summer but looked more impressive during the fall. His senior season got cancelled, though he did show some electric stuff during a preseason bullpen workout. While he's far from a finished product, Misiorowski has the 6-foot-6 build and raw stuff to dream on and think that he has a chance to become another Adam Wainwright. He has a quick arm that produces 90-94 mph fastballs with high spin rates and backspin action, and his frame has plenty of room to add strength and velocity. He has developed an overhand curveball that can be a hammer at its best and has surpassed his slider, which can reach the mid-80s with bite. Misiorowski still is learning to keep his long limbs in sync, so his control and command remain works in progress, as does his changeup. He has made improvements to his delivery and strike-throwing since last summer, though he didn't get a chance to show them off in game action this spring. He'll pitch at Oklahoma State if he doesn't sign this summer.

Name: Robby Ashford
Description: One of the better athletes in the 2020 Draft, Ashford is a four-star quarterback recruit who originally planned to play two sports at Mississippi until the Rebels made a football coaching change, prompting him to switch to Oregon. He's the fifth player to participate in both the Under Armour All-America baseball and football games, following Kyler Murray and A.J. Brown, who starred in the NFL as rookies last season, and Jerrion Ealy and Maurice Hampton, who are currently playing both sports in the Southeastern Conference. Ashford's desire to play football and rawness on the diamond make it unlikely that a team could pay him enough to get him to commit full-time to baseball, so he may go undrafted, but based purely on ceiling he could fit in the top three rounds. Ashford's most obvious tool is his speed, as he can produce top-of-the-scale times from home to first and chase balls down from gap to gap in center field. The strength in his 6-foot-4, 204-pound frame and the quickness of his right-handed swing give him the ingredients for plus raw power. And not surprisingly for a quarterback, he has a strong arm that would fit anywhere in the outfield. The huge question with Ashford is whether he'll hit enough to make the most of his pop and his speed on the bases. Playing football detracts from the time he needs to improve at the plate, and his pitch recognition and strike-zone management have looked rudimentary in his rare exposure to high-level competition. The demands of quarterbacking also will cut into his at-bats with the Ducks, so it will be difficult for him to reach his baseball potential.

Name: Caden Grice
Description: Scouts are split on whether Grice offers more upside as a slugger or a pitcher, but they all agree that it's a shame he didn't get a full high school senior season to figure it out. Some evaluators see top-of-the-scale raw power, while others see a southpaw with the makings of three solid pitches. He's built along the lines of Joey Gallo, who had a similar profile (albeit with more fastball velocity) coming out of high school. At 6-foot-6 and 240 pounds, Grice has impressive strength and leverage and offers some of the best raw pop in the 2020 Draft. He can topspin balls out of the park to center field, though his left-handed swing is naturally long and he'll need to tighten his strike zone and prove he can catch up to good velocity to make the most of his power. He's a below-average runner but not a clogger, and he has enough athleticism and the solid arm strength to play on the outfield corners. Teams believe Grice prefers to hit, though his swing-and-miss issues eventually could land him on the mound, where he's also a work in progress. He can run his fastball up to 94 mph with some sink but also sits in the upper 80s at times, and his slider and fading changeup have their moments but lack consistency. The Clemson recruit throws strikes but scouts don't love his arm action, which is long in back and features a high elbow.

Name: Adam Seminaris
Description: Long Beach State has a long history of producing big leaguers, from Evan Longoria to Jered Weaver. Seminaris, who joined the Dirtbags rotation full-time as a sophomore, then pitched well on the Cape last summer and carried that over to the start of the 2020 season, should break that schneid. Seminaris is, in many ways, the prototypical pitchability lefty, one with a four-pitch mix and excellent knowledge of how to use it. While his fastball typically sits 88-90 mph, and tops out at 93 mph, it plays up because he commands it so well and there??s deception in his delivery. He throws two breaking balls, with his mid-70s curve a bit better than his low-80s slider. But his best secondary offering is his plus changeup that misses bats and gets weak contact. Seminaris has always thrown a ton of strikes and was taking a step forward before the season was shut down this spring. He has a limited ceiling, but with his feel for pitching and track record, he??ll be enticing as a potential back-end starting pitcher.

Name: Stevie Emanuels
Description: The best right-hander to come out of the University of Washington was Tim Lincecum, a first-round pick of the Giants in 2006. Emanuels won't enter into those kinds of conversations, but after two years as a reliever and a solid Cape Cod League performance, followed by a move to the rotation this spring, he was opening eyes before the season shut down. Long and athletic, the 6-foot-5 Emanuels has an ideal pitcher??s frame, though he doesn??t always take full advantage of it. He throws his low-90s fastball, one that will touch 95 mph, with a loose arm and the ball jumps out of his hand, getting on the hitter in a hurry to create a lot of late swings. That happens even though he??s a bit of a short-strider with his delivery and finishes a bit upright. He??ll sometimes show two distinct breaking balls, but they often blend into an average pitch that is more slider than curve. He??ll mix in an average changeup as well. Emanuels tends to be around the strike zone, though he doesn??t have pinpoint command. It??s possible there??s more in the tank velocity-wise as he adds weight and strength. A team taking him would likely send him out as a starter to see if what he showed this spring is for real, knowing that everything would tick up a bit if he ended up back in the bullpen.

Name: Johnny Ray
Description: Ray has worked just 29 1/3 innings in three seasons of college, missing all of 2018 at Illinois State following Tommy John surgery. After emerging as one of the nation's best junior college prospects at John A. Logan (Ill.) CC that fall, he pitched in just eight frames last spring because of an oblique injury, then made four starts at Texas Christian in 2020 before the college season ended prematurely. His best outing came in front of several scouts in February, when he beat Minnesota and projected early first-round pick Max Meyer with a two-hit shutout. Ray can run his fastball up to 97 mph but usually pitches at 91-94 with late running action. He utilizes two distinct breaking balls, an upper-70s curveball with good depth and a cutter/slider that can reach 90 mph. He also exhibits feel for an upper-70s changeup with some fade and sink. All four of Ray's pitches can flash as plus, though he lacks consistency because of his inexperience. He has cleaned up his delivery some since injuring his elbow in high school and while he doesn't have the smoothest mechanics, he has thrown strikes in his limited action. His stuff could fit in the top three rounds but it's unclear how much teams will hold his lack of track record against him.

Name: Joe Boyle
Description: Though he could have factored into the top three rounds as a Kentucky high schooler in 2017, Boyle opted out of the Draft because he was set on attending Notre Dame. He had trouble throwing strikes in his first two seasons with the Fighting Irish and totaled just 27 2/3 innings as a result. He did make progress in the Cape Cod League last summer, giving some hope that he can harness his electric stuff, but he walked 13 batters in 8 1/3 innings during the shortened 2020 college season. Boyle has the best arm strength in the 2020 Draft. His fastball reached 102 mph in the Northwoods League during the summer of 2018 and hit 101 at the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament and on the Cape in 2019. He can operate in the upper 90s for several innings at a time while getting riding action on his heater. Boyle also can overpower hitters with an upper-80s slider but has yet to show much of a third pitch. His huge 6-foot-7 frame adds to his intimidation factor yet he has difficulty keeping all his long levers in sync and locating his pitches where he wants. He's a decent athlete, so there's optimism that he can continue to improve when he gets more regular innings in pro ball.

Name: Luke Little
Description: San Jacinto (Texas) JC has produced 18 big league pitchers, most notably Roger Clemens and Andy Pettitte, as well as Nationals 2019 first-rounder Jackson Rutledge. The Gators' three best arms -- right-hander Brandon Birdsell and lefties Little and Mitchell Parker -- all could fit in the first five rounds this year. Little tweaked his back after his first start in February and missed four weeks, then came back to make four relief appearances before the season ended early. Little has the highest maximum velocity of any southpaw in the 2020 Draft and created buzz when video surfaced of him hitting 105 mph in an indoor workout in May, though he tends to work at 93-96 in longer outings. He has made progress with his secondary pitches but they still need more work. His low-80s slider is his No. 2 option, and he also has come up with an upper-70s curveball and a nascent changeup. Little has gotten in much better shape this season, dropping 30 pounds from his massive 6-foot-8 frame and doing a better job of repeating his delivery in limited action, though scouts still don't care for his arm action or mechanics. He tallied 86 strikeouts versus 39 walks in 44 1/3 innings in two years at San Jacinto, and it's difficult to project him as more than a reliever who can air out his fastball in short stints. If he doesn't sign this summer, he'll pitch at South Carolina in 2021.

Name: Joey Wiemer
Description: Cincinnati's best prospect since Ian Happ was a Cubs first-rounder in 2016, Wiemer offers some of the best tools in the 2020 college crop but little track record of doing damage at the plate. He has a big league body (6-foot-5, 215 pounds) and three tools that grade as plus or better, yet he's a career .264/.379/.408 hitter for the Bearcats and slugged just .354 with wood bats in the Cape Cod League last summer. Wiemer's bat speed, strength and leverage give him plus raw power from the right side of the plate, but he's still figuring how to translate it into production. He utilizes a big leg kick and he has an uphill, max-effort swing and timing issues that lead to a lot of groundball contact. He probably will need to overhaul his stroke at the next level, though he does show some patience at the plate. Wiemer has plus speed and an aggressive nature on the bases, showing a knack for stealing bags. He has well above-average arm strength and has hit 98 mph on the mound, though a lack of control undermined him when Cincinnati briefly tried to use him as a closer this spring. He has played left field for the Bearcats, though his quickness and arm would suggest he can handle any outfield assignment.

Name: Jack Blomgren
Description: A classic glue guy who helps hold a team together, Blomgren won Michigan's shortstop job as a freshman and has started 137 of the Wolverines' 141 games over the last three seasons. He hit .360 at the 2019 College World Series as Michigan lost in the finals, its best finish since winning the 1962 national title. His makeup stands out more than any of his individual tools but he makes contact at the plate and plays in the field. Blomgren's speed and pure arm strength are just average, but his range and throwing are better than that. He has reliable hands, good instincts that help him reach grounders and a quick release and internal clock that allow him to get the ball across the diamond in plenty of time. He's capable of playing shortstop at the next level and has the skills to serve all over the infield in a utility role if needed. It remains to be seen whether Blomgren can provide enough offensive impact to profile as a big league regular. He makes consistent contact with a flat right-handed swing and his patience and knack for getting hit by pitches enhance his on-base skills. He sprays line drives to all fields but offers ordinary bat speed and little power, as evidenced by his .357 slugging percentage in college.

Name: Carson Ragsdale
Description: Ragsdale spent his first two years at the University of South Florida missing bats, and walking hitters, coming out of the bullpen. He then missed the 2019 season because he needed Tommy John surgery. A move to the rotation upon his return in 2020 created some serious buzz for the big right-hander, though he was only able to make four starts before the season was ended. There??s a lot to like about Ragsdale, starting with his 6-foot-8 frame that allows him to throw with a good downhill plane. He features a fastball that??s typically in the 91-95 mph range right now, but there??s room for more velocity in the future. He couples it with a curveball that flashes plus and can be a real strikeout pitch when he lands it in the strike zone. He has a changeup, but it??s a distant third pitch and will need to be developed at the next level. Ragsdale threw a lot of strikes this spring, but is still more control than command at this point. Given that scouts only saw four outings from Ragsdale as USF??s Sunday starter, there??s very limited track record for teams to look at, but his size and arm strength, even if it ends up in the bullpen, could be enough for teams to take a chance on him in this year??s Draft.

Name: Casey Opitz
Description: Since turning down the Indians as a 27th-rounder out of high school in 2017, Opitz has become one of the best defensive catchers in college baseball. He had the best caught-stealing percentage (48 percent) and fewest passed balls (two in 58 games) among Southeastern Conference backstops in 2019, when he helped the Razorbacks reach the College World Series in his first season as a starter. He also impressed behind the plate with the U.S. collegiate national team last summer, splitting time with projected first-round pick Patrick Bailey. Opitz's pure arm strength grades closer to average but plays at plus because he has such a quick transfer and release and he makes extremely accurate throws. He's a solid receiver and blocker who moves well, and he earns praise for his game-calling skills and leadership. He's the complete package defensively, which could lead to a long big league career as at least a backup. As much as scouts love his work as a catcher, they're not sold Opitz will hit enough to be a regular at the next level after watching him bat .253 with four homers in 93 college games. A switch-hitter who's better from the left side, he has a patient approach but doesn't make much hard contact. He has added some strength, shows glimpses of raw power as a lefty and performed better during the brief 2020 season, offering some hope that there's more offensive production to come.

Name: Jimmy Glowenke
Description: The Missouri Valley Conference freshman and defensive player of the year in 2018, Glowenke finished fourth in the league in batting (.328) last spring and then hit .296 in the Cape Cod League. One of the better hitters among this year's college shortstops, he missed the first weekend of his junior year recovering from offseason elbow surgery and didn't play in the field before the season ended. He could go in the first five rounds and is a righty-hitting version of the only Dallas Baptist infielder ever to do so (Ryan Goins, fourth round, 2009), albeit with less arm strength. Glowenke's lone better-than-average tool is his bat, as he makes line-drive contact with ease. He controls the strike zone well and enhances his on-base ability by getting hit by more than his share of pitches. He can provide some doubles and perhaps 10-12 homers per season at the next level, but he didn't drive the ball with wood bats on the Cape.  Glowenke's below-average speed almost certainly will push him to second base in pro ball. He's a sure-handed defender at shortstop, but he lacks the range to stay there. His average arm may be enough to get by at third base in a utility role, though neither it nor his power fits the profile to play regularly at the hot corner.

Name: Blake Dunn
Description: Western Michigan hasn't produced a big leaguer since Adam Rosales went in the 12th round of the 2005 Draft, but Dunn has the upside to end that drought. He earned 16 letters in four sports at Saugatuck (Mich.) High, finishing as the second-leading scorer in state football history (827 points), winning six state championships in hurdles and scoring 51 points in a single basketball game. He's one of the top college athletes in the Draft but a rough summer in the Cape Cod League has raised questions about his hitting ability. Dunn has been clocked at 6.32 seconds in a 60-yard dash on artificial turf, and he translates his plus-plus speed into dynamic basestealing ability and quality defense in center field. His arm is also a weapon, with his fastball registering up to 95 mph during his sporadic appearances on the mound. He also offers plus raw power from the right side of the plate. Those tools could have landed Dunn in the top two or three rounds if he hadn't hit .229/.338/.298 with a 25 percent strikeout rate on the Cape. He has some timing issues at the plate and will chase balls up in the strike zone, though he does employ a patient approach. He has yet to prove he can tap into his power on a regular basis, hitting just seven homers in 108 college games.

Name: Jacob Teter
Description: Lightly recruited out of high school, Teter landed at Division II Florida Southern and immediately showed off a good approach at the plate, earning conference Freshman of the Year honors. After another off-the-radar, but solid, season as a sophomore, he got noticed by scouts with a very solid performance in the Cape Cod League last summer and he had gotten off to a very good start over his first 22 games this spring before the shutdown. The 6-foot-6 first baseman creates an imposing presence in the left side of the batter??s box. He??s had impressive plate discipline throughout his college career, with more walks than strikeouts and even though there??s some length to his swing, he??s shown an ability to make consistent contact. There??s plenty of raw power for him to tap into, something he??s done at times in college, and with more to come once he learns to lift the ball more consistently. Limited to first base, Teter is capable at the infield corner, though it??s clearly his bat that will have teams interested, especially those who like college performers. Playing against Division II competition might make some pause, but his Cape performance should help offset that for teams intrigued by his left-handed power potential.

Name: Christian Chamberlain
Description: While fellow Draft prospect Kevin Abel was the star freshman pitcher for Oregon State??s College World Series title run in 2018, Chamberlain made a strong contribution as a freshman reliever himself, tying a CWS record with 11 strikeouts in one relief outing. After his sophomore year coming out of the pen, the left-hander moved to the rotation as a junior in 2020 and raised his profile with a very solid four-start beginning to the spring. The sub-6-footer has a three-pitch mix that could give him the chance to start. He can run his fastball up to 95 mph, though as a starter his velocity backed off after a few innings to around 90-91 mph. Chamberlain throws it with good riding life, and he likes to throw it up in the zone to miss bats. His curve is close to a 12-to-6 breaking ball with good bite that can miss a lot of bats, one that was responsible for eight of his 11 K??s in that CWS performance. He can mix in an average changeup as well. While Chamberlain has missed a ton of bats throughout his Beavers career, striking out 12 per nine -- a rate that spiked to 13.9 over his four starts -- he??s struggled to throw strikes consistently. A team taking him in the Draft might send him out as a starter to see if he can refine his command, but there??s a good chance he ends up back in the bullpen, where his fastball-curve combination would play up.

Name: Kyle Hurt
Description: Hurt was a Top 100 Draft prospect coming out of the San Diego high school ranks in 2017, but a combination of a knee injury and a strong commitment to Southern Cal led to him not being selected until the 34th round and he headed to campus. He??s been up-and-down for much of his Trojans career, though he did take over as the Friday night starter during his sophomore year, a role he held at the start of the 2020 season before things were shut down. Hurt has long had the size and pure stuff to make him a very strong pitching prospect. His fastball will sit in the 92-94 range and he will top out at 97 mph, and he could find more consistent velocity at the top end of that scale as he continues to add strength to his 6-foot-3 frame. His best secondary pitch is his changeup, which could be a plus pitch in time. He throws both a hard slider in the upper-80s and a slower, upper-70s curve, both of which show glimpses but are inconsistent breaking pitches. The right-hander hasn??t always commanded his stuff well or maintained it deep into starts, with the sharpness of his stuff often varying from outing to outing. He entered the spring as one of the more enigmatic college pitching prospects in this class and there wasn??t really enough time for scouts?? questions to be completely answered this spring.

Name: Sterlin Thompson
Description: North Marion High School in Central Florida has had four players drafted from its baseball program, none since 1993 and none higher than James Morgan, a 16th-round pick of the Indians back in 1990. While Thompson did not participate in many of the big showcase events last summer, an All-Tournament showing at Perfect Game??s World Wood Bat Association World Championship in Jupiter, Fla., last fall put him more on the map, and there was an up arrow next to his name with a good start to his spring before the season was shut down. Long and lean, Thompson has a projectable body and he should be able to add strength to his 6-foot-3 frame. That means there should be even more power to come from his nice left-handed swing that already has good launch angle and loft, giving him the chance to be an average hitter with at least average pop in the future. While scouts feel confident he??ll hit, there??s less certainty about where his long-term defensive home will be. A shortstop in high school, Thompson has decent hands and a strong arm, but his actions can be a bit long and he??s likely going to fill out and slow down more. Some evaluators see a move to third, while others think he might be suited to be an offensive-minded second baseman. And some feel that a team taking him should just put him in left field and let his bat play. If the Draft doesn??t work out and he heads to the University of Florida, he would be eligible again in 2022 as a sophomore.

Name: Will Klein
Description: Eastern Illinois' best prospect since Tyler Kehler went in 2009's supplemental first round to the Angels, Klein recorded a 5.74 ERA in his first two college seasons while serving mostly as a reliever. He broke out in the Northwoods League last summer, reaching 99 mph during the wood-bat circuit's all-star game and finishing with a 0.86 ERA and 38 strikeouts in 21 innings. After the Panthers moved him into their rotation this spring, he continued to make progress with his breaking ball and control. As a starter in 2020, Klein worked at 92-94 mph and topped out at 96 with his four-seam fastball, which is fairly straight but does feature some riding action. He also flashed a solid curveball with power and depth. He began incorporating a changeup into his repertoire, but it lacks velocity separation from his heater and lags well behind his other two offerings. While Klein shaved his walk rate from 9.8 per nine innings in his first two college seasons to 4.8 in his truncated third, he'll need to upgrade his control and command in order to remain a starter in pro ball. He has a strong 6-foot-5 frame built for durability but probably will wind up in the bullpen. In shorter stints, he could focus on his two best pitches and his fastball might park in the upper 90s.

Name: Nate Wohlgemuth
Description: Wohlgemuth hit 96 mph with his fastball as an Owasso (Okla.) High freshman in 2017, stamping him as the school's best prospect since Dylan Bundy went fourth overall in the 2011 Draft. He battled his control on the showcase circuit last summer but finished with one of the best performances in the history of the World Wood Bat Association World Championship, tossing a 14-strikeout no-hitter in October. Despite his velocity, he's a short high school right-hander with a reliever profile, so he might not fit in the first five rounds. When he's fresh, Wohlgemuth can sit in the mid-90s for multiple innings and top out at 98 mph with some armside run on his fastball. He lacks angle and plane on his heater, however, and there's some question as to how many bats he'll miss if he sits at 92-95 with more regular use. His mid-70s curveball shows flashes of becoming a plus pitch but also lacks consistency, and his mid-80s fading changeup is a more reliable offering. Though he's just 5-foot-11, and his listed height may be generous, Wohlgemuth doesn't throw with excessive effort and uses his legs well in his delivery. He has fairly simple mechanics and athleticism that should allow him to fill the strike zone, but his control and command are very scattered. The Arkansas recruit is strong but physically mature, so it's difficult to project his stuff getting any firmer, and he'll be Draft-eligible as a 21-year-old sophomore in 2022 if he attends college.

Name: Bobby Seymour
