Description: Seymour started at first base for Wake Forest as a freshman and exploded as a sophomore in 2019, winning Atlantic Coast Conference player of the year honors after leading the league in hitting (.377) and NCAA Division I in RBI (92, the most at that level since Buster Posey had 93 in 2008). An appendectomy cut short his summer in the Cape Cod League and with the U.S. collegiate national team, though he hit well with wood bats in the Northwoods League in 2018. He should go in the first five rounds as one of the better pure hitters in the college ranks. Despite being 6-foot-4 and 250 pounds, Seymour is a hit-over-power guy. He employs a very controlled approach during games, making hard line-drive contact and using the opposite field well rather than swinging for the fences. He's strong and displays at least solid raw power during batting practice, but some scouts worry about the fact that he homered just twice in 243 plate appearances with wood in two years of college summer league play. Seymour has to provide offensive production because he doesn't offer much else. He's a well below-average runner with below-average arm strength, limiting his defensive options to first base. An adequate defender at best, he could wind up at DH, which would increase the demands on his bat.

Name: Zach Brzykcy
Description: Brzykcy has been a reliever since he set foot on Virginia Tech??s campus from the North Carolina high school ranks three years ago, showcasing his power stuff but struggling mightily to find the strike zone with it. He opened a lot of eyes in the Cape Cod League last summer, throwing strikes and leading the league in saves en route to being named the league??s reliever of the year. He did not bring that feel for pitching with him at the start of the spring, but his pure stuff is still very enticing. The 6-foot-2 right-hander has the kind of fastball-slider combination you love to see coming out of the bullpen late in games. He touches triple digits fairly regularly, throwing his fastball anywhere in the 94-101 mph range, though it does get hit more than it should at times. His hard slider is a legitimate strikeout pitch and a nasty plus breaking ball.  The big issue is with Brzykcy??s command. While he has struck out nearly 14 batters per nine innings at Virginia Tech, he??s also walked a whopping 10.5. The team that believes it can help Brzycky become the reliever everyone saw on the Cape will be the one to take him.

Name: Patrick Reilly
Description: Over the summer, Northeast area high school pitchers like Alex Santos and Jason Savacool raised their stock on the showcase circuit. Reilly didn??t pitch much over the summer, but he opened a ton of eyes with his performance at Perfect Game??s WWBA World Championship in Jupiter, Fla., in the fall. Teams that saw him there were excited to follow up on him as the weather warmed up in his native New Jersey this spring, something that never happened because of coronavirus. Reilly has the ingredients to be a power starting pitcher in the future, but it??s all a bit raw. He was up to 96 mph during his start in Jupiter, and there??s a ton of projection in his 6-foot-3, 210-pound frame to point to more consistent velocity in the future. He can spin a breaking ball -- a pitch that flashes as a plus curve, but can get loopy and slurvy at times -- with some evaluators thinking he could eventually have two distinct options. His changeup is clearly behind his fastball-breaking ball combination, but there is some belief it could become a usable offering with more repetition. While he??s raw and doesn??t have great command right now, Reilly does have a workable delivery and clean arm action that point to decent control in the future. There??s a lot to like with this right-hander, but teams haven??t seen that much of him, making it trickier to figure out if they can sign him away from his commitment to Vanderbilt, the school he switched to from Northeastern following his performance in Jupiter.

Name: Kala'i Rosario
Description: In four of the last six Drafts, Hawaii has seen a high schooler get drafted in the top five rounds, headlined by 2014 first-round pick Kodi Medeiros. Rosario, who showed off his right-handed bat over last summer at events like the Area Code Games, gives the island state the chance to make it 5-for-7. All talk around Rosario centers around his bat, more specifically his plus-plus raw power. Rosario beat fellow Draft prospect Blaze Jordan in the Area Code Games home run derby last summer. He can get a little pull-happy and out front on his swing at times, and there are some concerns about his ability to hit enough to get to that raw pop consistently in games at the next level. Rosario is a decent athlete, and he does play center field in high school, but as a tick-below-average runner who is already fairly physically mature, he is likely going to be limited to a corner, with left field his likely destination. He does have the power potential to profile well in an outfield corner, and that could be enough for the California Baptist recruit to get drafted.

Name: Jamal O'Guinn
Description: A three-year starter at Southern Cal, O??Guinn showed glimpses of his ability over his first two years in the Trojans' lineup. He performed better as a Cape Cod League All-Star last summer and had gotten off to a hot start during his junior year before the shutdown, putting him in position to possibly become just the third USC hitter to go in the top five rounds in the last 10 years. Those who like O??Guinn point to his 6-foot-4, 220-pound frame, his offensive potential and his plate discipline. The right-handed hitter has always drawn a ton of walks, with a .420 on-base percentage in his Southern Cal career. He??ll show off plus raw power in batting practice, but hasn??t always tapped into it in games.  O??Guinn played third base this year because the Trojans needed someone at the hot corner, but while he??s not a bad athlete with an average arm, it??s unclear whether he can stick there. He??s played the first base and corner outfield spots in the past, and he could be fine in left. There??ll be pressure for his bat to produce at any of those spots, and there are teams who think it might, giving him the chance to be the first Trojans hitter to go in the top five rounds since catcher Jeremy Martinez was a fourth-round pick in 2016.

Name: Taylor Dollard
Description: After playing his high school ball in Encino, Dollard went north a bit in California to become a part of Cal Poly??s pitching staff. He spent his first two years coming out of the bullpen, earning first-team All-Big West Conference honors as a sophomore. After a strong turn in relief on the Cape last summer, Dollard looked very good in his first chance as a starter for the Mustangs this spring. Tall and athletic, Dollard has the chance to have a four-pitch mix that he knows how to use well, even if none of his individual offerings jump off the page. Velocity-wise, his fastball only sits in the 88-90 mph range, topping out at around 93 mph, but it plays up because of its sink and Dollard??s ability to command and manipulate it so well. His 77-80 mph slider is his out pitch and flashes plus at times, though he doesn??t always throw it hard enough and he can fold in a low-70s curveball with depth as well. Dollard doesn??t throw a ton of changeups, but he shows very good feel for it and it could end up being his best secondary pitch in the future. Dollard has walked just 2.2 per nine in his college career and walked only 1.3 over his four starts this spring. Some see a little Tom Eshelman in him, the Fullerton command artist who went in the second round back in 2015, though Dollard isn??t expected to come off the board quite as early.

Name: Alex Toral
Description: After a strong summer on the showcase circuit, Toral began his senior year of high school in 2017 in Florida as an intriguing power hitting first baseman worth following. But he struggled that spring and that, combined with his strong commitment to Miami, led to him not being drafted at all. Three years later, not a whole lot has changed other than some production against good college competition. Toral??s carrying tool is his power. He has easily plus raw power and is capable of hitting the ball out to all fields, and he did hit 24 homers during his sophomore season with the Hurricanes. That power comes with a ton of swing-and-miss concerns, with Toral having struck out in more than 26 percent of his college plate appearances. He does help offset that a bit with a solid walk rate, and his approach was improved -- albeit in a smaller sample size -- this spring. The first baseman??s bat is going to have to play because he??s a well-below-average runner who has been described as a ???bull in a china shop?? defensively. There??s risk here, but teams that covet legitimate power might be willing to roll the dice.

Name: Hunter Haas
Description: Over the last few years, there??s been a bit of a battle for the title of best Arizona high school shortstop in this class between Haas and Carson Tucker. Tucker has taken a large step forward to likely claim the overall crown, but Haas has the skills to stay up the middle, tools he showed off last summer to land a spot on the 18 and Under National Team for USA Baseball. Haas is the kind of player you like more the longer you see him, one who gets high marks as a gritty ???baseball player?? type more than for any individual tool. He does stand out with his glove work, with excellent hands and instincts at shortstop. He likely has enough arm to stay at the position, though some see that and a lack of foot speed as an indication he might eventually be better suited for second. Haas controls the bat very well, but there??s a lack of impact that concerns some. A player who is more than the sum of his parts, Haas is more instincts-and-feel than tools-oriented. Some see him more as a really good college player. Should he go on to Arizona State, he could be the type who emerges as a Cadyn Grenier type, the Oregon State shortstop who was the 37th overall pick in the 2018 Draft.

Name: Steven Ondina
Description: A year ago, the top player from Puerto Rico was shortstop Matthew Lugo, one of three middle infielders from the island in MLB Pipeline??s Top 200 in 2019 who went in the second round to the Red Sox. This year??s crop, while thinner, is also topped by a shortstop, Odina, who has some tools, albeit in a small package. Scouts love the way Ondina plays the game and think he has the chance to stay up the middle. He has excellent hands and footwork, with his speed helping him have excellent range, and it seems like he has enough arm to play at shortstop long-term. He??s also shown he can handle any infield position as well as run well enough to play center field, important attributes if he ends up being a utiity type. He has good bat-to-ball skills with the ability to hit the gaps, but there is concern about a lack of strength and how much he can impact the baseball. Ondina is generously listed at 5-foot-8 and a lot of scouts would like to see him go on to Florida International to see if he can add strength to his small frame. Teams who believe he??s a future everyday shortstop might take a chance and help him get bigger and stronger with pro instruction.

Name: Gino Groover
Description: Groover wasn't a regular on the high school showcase circuit but impressed evaluators with his bat speed at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship last October. He's a product of The Walker School (Marietta, Ga.), which also spawned No. 1 overall pick Mike Ivie and a second big leaguer in David Hale. Though he has been scouted less than most players on this list and the shortened high school season didn't help his cause, he's intriguing as a possible middle infielder with offensive upside. Groover's whippy right-handed swing and projectable 6-foot-3 frame could translate into average or better pop as he gains strength and experience. He already shows a knack for making hard line-drive contact, fueling optimism that he'll get to most of his power potential. He doesn't try to do too much at the plate, keeping his stroke compact and not expanding the strike zone. A high school shortstop, Groover almost certainly will change positions at the next level. He has reliable hands and good instincts, but his average speed and arm strength fit better at second base. Some scouts think the UNC Charlotte recruit could wind up at third base if his arm gets stronger or an outfield corner if he slows down as he fills out.

Name: Magdiel Cotto
Description: Yet another prep pitcher denied a full opportunity to show what he could do as a senior, Cotto whetted the appetites of scouts with a breakout performance at the Super 60 showcase in February. Relatively unknown after moving from Pennsylvania to South Carolina as a junior, he made a name for himself by reaching 95 mph with his fastball and pairing it with a sharp slider. He wasn't as electric during his truncated high school season, increasing the chances he winds up attending college at South Carolina. A big left-hander, Cotto operated more at 87-92 mph this spring after sitting at 92-94 during the Super 60 workout. He uses his 6-foot-3 frame and high three-quarters slot to create downhill plane on his fastball, which also features some running action. He has tightened his breaking ball, a low-80s slider with solid potential, and also exhibits some feel for his changeup. Cotto doesn't throw with much effort, though he's more physical than athletic and doesn't pound the strike zone. With a chance for a three-pitch mix and a durable build, he offers the upside of a starter. But evaluators wanted to see him sustain his Super 60 performance, so it's unclear where he might go in the Draft.

Name: Elijah Cabell
Description: Two years ago, Cabell??s raw tools coming out of the TNXL Baseball Academy in Florida put him at No. 101 on MLB Pipeline??s Top 200 and got him drafted by the Brewers in the 14th round of the 2018 Draft. He made a late switch from a commitment to LSU to one with Florida State in the middle of June to keep him in-state after he didn??t sign with Milwaukee. Now back as a Draft-eligible sophomore, he??s still very much the toolsy-but-raw player he was in high school. Cabell can do a lot of things well on the baseball field, but his standout tool might be his raw power. Some scouts put a 70 on his raw pop, but there are a lot of questions about his ability to get to that power with any consistency given how frequently he strikes out. He was hitting more homers this spring before the season was cancelled and he draws walks, but his inability to recognize pitches is very concerning. Far from a burner, Cabell is athletic enough to be a capable defensive outfielder with plenty of arm strength for an outfield corner. It??s easy to love the tools, but will teams believe he's going to make enough contact to keep him from heading back for his junior year with the Seminoles?

Name: Jackson Fristoe
Description: Fristoe's stuff and performance varied on the showcase circuit last summer, as he mixed good and rough outings at the PDP League, struggled to throw strikes at East Coast Pro and rebounded with his best effort at the Area Code Games. Scouts were looking forward to seeing what progress he might make this spring, but the Kentucky high school season got cancelled before he even took the mound. That may make it difficult to take him early enough to divert him from Mississippi State, where he'd be Draft-eligible as a 21-year-old sophomore in 2022. Fristoe's fastball ranged from 88-90 mph to 91-94 at different times last summer, featuring some armside run. He has a very projectable 6-foot-4 build and could sit in the mid-90s once he matures physically. He lacks consistency with his secondary offerings but shows the promise of a four-pitch arsenal with flashes of a low-80s slider, a curveball with more depth than power and the makings of a changeup. Because he's still growing into his tall frame, Fristoe doesn't always keep his long limbs in sync in his delivery on a consistent basis. His control and command are still works in progress but should get better as he improves his strength and mechanics. He could blossom into a top-two-rounds prospect after a couple of seasons in the Southeastern Conference.

Name: Max Carlson
Description: Sam Carlson saw his fastball jump from 88-92 mph as a Minnesota high school junior to 93-97 as a senior, propelling him into the second round and a $2-million bonus from the Mariners. His younger brother Max isn't as big or projectable as Sam was, but scouts were eager to see if he might make a similar leap as a senior this spring. He impressed in a February bullpen workout but didn't get a chance to pitch in games, which will make it tough to draft him high enough to sign him away from a North Carolina commitment. Carlson thrived on the showcase circuit last summer while his fastball sat mostly in the upper 80s with some run and sink, then opened some eyes by operating at 90-94 mph at the World Wood Bat Association World Championship in October. He has the makings of a pair of solid secondary pitches in his slider and circle changeup, both of which park in the upper 70s. His curveball has gotten sharper as he has gotten stronger, while his changeup features fade and sink. Carlson's stuff plays up because he commands it well, showing the ability to spot his fastball on both sides of the plate and sneak it by hitters up in the strike zone on occasion. Scouts also like his mound presence and competitiveness. His 6-foot-1 frame doesn't have a lot of projection remaining but he's more polished than most high school pitchers.

Name: Tyson Guerrero
Description: Guerrero started his collegiate career as a two-way player at Washington State in 2019 as an outfielder and a relief pitcher. He transferred to Lower Columbia Community College in Washington, making him eligible for the Draft this year. Still hitting and pitching, his Draft stock on the mound jumped when he showed better stuff, albeit in a very small sample size, early this spring. As a high schooler, Guerrero was an undersized player who needed college experience. He??s since added good weight and strength, and that??s resulted in better stuff on the mound. While the southpaw only had two starts before the shutdown, he showed off his quick arm and willingness to attack hitters with a potential three-pitch mix. He??ll get his fastball up to the mid-90s at times and his curveball gives him a true out pitch, one that bites with late, downer action. He has a changeup, but it??s behind the other two offerings. That wipeout breaking ball was on full display in his second start of the spring, when he recorded 15 strikeouts in six innings. While he??s not going to hit at the next level, the athleticism he shows in playing both ways should help him on the mound as he gets more reps, with improved command likely. He doesn??t have the same command, but some in the area think he reminds them of another small, but athletic lefty from the region who was a first-rounder in 2013: Marco Gonzales.

Name: Carson Taylor
Description: Taylor got considerable playing time as a freshman at Virginia Tech in 2019, splitting time between catching and first base. He became the Hokies?? primary catcher as a Draft-eligible sophomore and was added to the 2020 Buster Posey National Collegiate Catcher of the Year Award watch list. He was off to a very hot start before the season was ended, raising his profile especially among teams who value college performers. Taylor has considerable bat speed from both sides of the plate. He??s shown a good feel for the strike zone and has walked more than he??s struck out in his college career. While there??s a lot of raw power to tap into, Taylor gets pull-happy and out front on his swing too often to get to it consistently. He can make hard contact, but pitches on the outer third of the plate gave him trouble. While he does have an average arm behind the plate, his overall receiving skills are below average, leading to some concerns about his ability to stick there. But there could be teams interested in seeing if that will work and buying the bat, perhaps looking at a move to first base or left field, or at least splitting time among positions in the future.

Name: Dylan MacLean
Description: There??s no question that the best high school arm in the state of Oregon belongs to Mick Abel, a likely first-round pick. No. 2 on that list, and the best lefty from the area, is MacLean, a super-projectable southpaw who entices with his ability to command his stuff as well as potential future gains in velocity and stuff. MacLean has long been known for his feel for pitching, but as a tall, skinny lefty who was throwing in the mid-80s at the Area Code Games last summer, he seemed ticketed to head to the University of Washington to become an outstanding Draft prospect three years from now. But while he didn??t really get to pitch this spring, he did touch 92 mph in workouts and on video. While that doesn??t automatically translate to that much velocity increase in game situations, it is a sign that he has added strength to his 6-foot-3 frame.  His fastball already played up because of his ability to command it to all quadrants of the strike zone. His low-70s curveball has some depth and his changeup gives him a third at-least future average pitch, all coming from a fluid arm action. There??d be some risk involved in terms of drafting him and signing him away form his Huskies commitment, but the ceiling might be enough to convince teams to take a chance.

Name: Braiden Ward
Description: As a kid, Ward was a standout BMX racer. In high school, he was the goalie on the El Capitan High School Water Polo team. But his skills on the baseball field, most notably his speed, got him to the University of Washington, where he??s been a starter for three years. A Cape Cod League All-Star last summer, he led the PAC-12 in stolen bases all three seasons, including the most recent one shortened by the pandemic.  Ward has very close to top-of-the-scale speed, leading some to say he??s like the college version of Florida prepster Enrique Bradfield Jr. Not only does he record plus-plus times in the 60 and home to first, but he has outstanding base-stealing instincts and is a threat to run on any pitch. He uses a slashing approach at the plate and can shoot the ball to all fields, and while he??s not a power hitter, there??s more strength than you??d think when looking at his frame. Ward??s speed combined with his excellent instincts add up to a plus defender in the outfield, albeit one with a fringy arm, who will be able to play center for a long time. His offensive profile might be a bit limited, but that speed tool is a hard one to find. That, along with a track record of using that speed well against good competition, should help him when the Draft comes around.

Name: Jacob Berry
Description: Scouts went to Arizona early and often during the abbreviated spring season, largely to see the deep college crop that starts with No. 1 prospect Spencer Torkelson at Arizona State. They also could get looks at high school infielders like Carson Tucker, Hunter Haas and Berry, who showed off his power potential as a home run derby participant in the Area Code Games last summer and swung the bat well during his brief senior year. The six-foot corner infielder is a switch-hitter whose best tool is his bat. When it all clicks, he??s an average hitter with plus power that can show up in games. He??s better overall from the left side, with a better feel to hit, more bat speed and more natural loft, but while he??s stiffer from the right side, the strength is still there for him to hit the ball out. While scouts feel like he??s going to hit, there are some questions about where he plays defensively long-term. He??s played shortstop in high school, and has raw arm strength, but doesn??t have the foot speed to stay there. A move to third might make the most sense, and he has caught in the past, while some see a move to left or even a Max Muncy-type of switch to second base if he can be signed away from his commitment to Arizona.

Name: Levi Prater
Description: Oklahoma's entire weekend rotation could fit in the first five rounds of the 2020 Draft. Cade Cavalli is a lock first-rounder and Dane Acker threw a no-hitter against Louisiana State, but Prater had a better ERA (3.42) than either of them this spring. Scouts admire his perseverance and competitiveness, which helped him overcome a lawnmower accident that cost him two fingers on his non-pitching hand when he was not quite 2 years old. Prater's fastball parks around 90-91 mph and tops out at 93 with enough armside run to keep it off barrels. His slider hovers around 80 mph and is tough on left-handers because he sets up on the first-base side of the rubber and throws across his body. His changeup has similar velocity and fades well enough to keep right-handers at bay. Prater's delivery features some effort and his control is just decent, yet his pure stuff plays better than its fringy to average grades. He has managed to outpitch and miss more bats than Cavalli in each of their three seasons together with the Sooners. It's easy to say that Prater profiles more as a middle reliever, but his track record and his makeup may allow him to become a back-of-the-rotation starter.

Name: Matt Mikulski
Description: Fordham University has seen just six players taken in the first 10 rounds of the MLB Draft since Pete Harnisch was a supplemental first rounder back in 1987. Harnisch went on to a 14-year career in the big leagues, almost entirely as a starter. Mikulski should add to that draft total this year. It seems more likely that his path to the big leagues will be out of the bullpen, though he threw well as a starter last summer on the Cape and at the start of his junior season this spring. Mikulski is a southpaw who has the chance to mix three pitches into his arsenal. He??ll throw his fastball up to 95 mph, especially in shorter stints, sitting more in the 90-92 mph range as a starter. His slider is a potential plus pitch -- one that misses a ton of bats -- and he can mix in a usable changeup, as well. Hitters have a hard time picking up the ball thanks to a deceptive delivery with a lot of moving parts. That delivery, which some would call violent, also has led to some command issues, leading many evaluators to think he won??t be able to start long-term. A team taking him could send him out as a starter to see if that can be ironed out, but he could move quickly through a system as a left-handed reliever.

Name: Ryan Bruno
Description: Projectable high school pitchers show up in every Draft class and their tendency to be high risk, high reward is well-documented. When those pitchers are left-handed, that can get scouts' attention even more. Bruno, who plays for an American Heritage High School-Delray program in Florida that has produced professional players like Antoan Richardson and, more recently, Jonathan India, has a ton of upside, albeit with some concerns about his control. Bruno has an intriguing combination of size, projection, arm strength and, of course, left-handedness. He can get his fastball up to 95 mph at times, but sits more comfortably in the low-90s. He throws a three-quarters breaking ball that's a bit of a hybrid but looks more like a curve than a slider. He has a changeup, but he tends to get under it and he misses up and to the arm side with it. Bruno struggled to command his stuff over the summer, with a tendency to overthrow with too much effort and a head dive that impacts his release point. When Bruno has managed to not overthrow, his mechanics stay in sync and he's thrown more strikes. With his build, it's easy to dream on growth across the board. His command issues that plagued him over the summer, along with him building up arm strength in the early spring, had him pitching in relief early in the spring, though there were some reports of improved control right when the season shut down. That, along with his commitment to Stanford, make it tougher to see him selected in a five-round Draft.

Name: Oraj Anu
Description: Oraj is a switch-hitter who homered from both sides of the plate in a game for Kentucky this year. His mother, Oralee, was an Olympic sprinter for the Bahamas who competed in the women's 4x100 meter relay in the 1984 Olympics in Los Angeles.

Name: Jaren Shelby
Description: Jaren posted a .384 on-base percentage over the past two seasons at Kentucky. His dad, also an outfielder, won World Series rings with the 1983 Orioles and 88 Dodgers and has held several other coaching jobs throughout the Majors and Minors. His cousin, Josh Harrison, is a nine-year MLB veteran, spending most of that time with the Pirates.

Name: Andres Perez
Description: Andres is the son of Eddie Perez, who was MVP of the 1999 NL Championship Series and spent a lot of his career catching Greg Maddux. Andres was drafted by the Braves in 2016, but went on to North Georgia, where he hit .330 with 23 homers in 53 games as a sophomore in 18 before missing the next year due to injury. He had six home runs in nine games before the 2020 season was cut short.

Name: Jason Ruffcorn
Description: Jason is the son of Scott Ruffcorn, a right-hander who pitched in parts of five Major League seasons for the White Sox and Phillies.

Name: Kyle Hess
Description: As a sophomore at Pitt, Kyle hit .373/.425/.627 in the shortened 2020 season. His cousin, Chris Heisey, was a 17th-round pick by Cincinnati in 2006, and spent time with the Reds, Dodgers and Nationals.

Name: Kyle Karros
Description: Kyle is committed to UCLA, where his older brother, Jared, is a pitcher. Eric, Kyles father, also played for the Bruins and was selected in the sixth round of the 1988 Draft by the Dodgers, taking home NL Rookie of the Year honors in 1992. He went on to hit 284 homers in the big leagues as a first baseman, spending most of his career in L.A.

Name: Tommy Bell
Description: Tommy is the nephew of Terry Bell, a first-round pick of the Mariners in the 1983 Draft who made his Major League debut in 1986 with Kansas CIty.

Name: Garrett Bevacqua
Description: Garrett's dad was a pinch-hitter extraordinaire for 15 big league seasons with six different teams from 1971-85. Bevacqua's career highlight was the 1984 World Series with the Padres -- San Diego fell to the juggernaut Tigers, but a 37-year-old Bevacqua hit .412 with a pair of homers.

Name: Ian McWilliams
Description: Ian is the younger brother of Sam McWilliams, a Rays minor leaguer.

Name: Mariano Ricciardi
Description: Mariano is the son of J.P., who is the former GM of the Blue Jays and a current senior advisor with the Giants.

Name: Will Proctor
Description: James grandfather, Jim Proctor, made two Major League appearances in 1959 for the Tigers.

Name: Luke Eldred
Description: Luke is the son of Cal, also a right-handed pitcher, who was taken 17th overall in the 1989 Draft by the Brewers and went on to pitch almost 1,400 big league innings. Cal is now the pitching coach for the Royals, who also have Lukes brother, C.J., as a pitcher in their Minor League system.

Name: Jamison Hill
Description: Jamisons step-grandfather Garry Templeton might be best known as part of the trade that sent Ozzie Smith to St. Louis, but he was an excellent player in his own right. The three-time All-Star shortstop collected more than 2,000 hits and 200 steals over 16 MLB seasons.

Name: Jayden Hill
Description: Jayden is the son of former NFL running back Greg Hill, who was drafted 25th overall in 1994 out of Texas A&M and went on to rush for 772 yards and 12 touchdowns over six seasons for the Chiefs, Rams and Lions.

Name: Tristan Weaver
Description: Tristan is the son of Eric, who spent time with the Dodgers, Mariners and Angels as a pitcher.

Name: Drew Brutcher
Description: Drew is the son of Lenny Brutcher, a second-round pick in the 1988 Draft who played five seasons in the Minor Leagues in the White Sox and Padres organizations.

Name: Gunner Halter
Description: Gunner has already been drafted in both 2017 (Blue Jays, 22nd round) and 18 (Indians, 26th round), and bounced from Seminole State to Mississippi State to Oklahoma City. His dad, a Royals fifth-round pick in 1991, held on to a utility role in Detroit in the early 2000s and played all nine positions in a game in 2000.

Name: Jake Boone
Description: Jake could represent the fourth generation of Boones, who thus far have produced four big leaguers, each of whom made at least one All-Star team. Jake, a 38th-round pick by the Nationals in 2017, batted .312 and led Princeton in hits as a sophomore last year.

Name: Jack Dreyer
Description: Jack is the son of Steve Dreyer,  an eighth-round pick of the Rangers in 1990 who pitched in 15 games across two big league seasons for Texas.

Name: Shane McGuire
Description: Shane was batting a ridiculous .469 in 12 games as a junior for the Toreros before the 2020 season was cut short. His older brother, Reese, was the No. 14 overall pick in the 2013 Draft by the Pirates, was traded to the Blue Jays in 16 and has posted an .882 OPS through his first 44 MLB games.

Name: Tora Otsuka
Description: Tora is the son of Akinori, who enjoyed great success as a reliever in Japan before making the jump to the Majors as a 32-year-old in 2004, when he finished third in NL Rookie of the Year Award voting by posting a 1.75 ERA for the Padres.

Name: Cam Williams
Description: Cam is the son of Reggie Williams, an outfielder who played for the Angels and Dodgers across four big league seasons.

Name: Duke Ellis
Description: Duke is the son of Robert Ellis, a third-round pick in the 1990 Draft who pitched in four Major League seasons for the Angels, D-backs, Dodgers and Rangers.

Name: Cole Percival
Description: A righty just like his dad, Cole passed up signing with the D-backs as a 31st-rounder in 2017, and headed to college, where he posted a 3.38 ERA in four starts before the 2020 season was cut short. Troy, who also played at Riverside, was picked in the sixth round in 1990 by the Angels. He became a four-time All-Star closer for the Halos, helping the club win the 2002 World Series, and ranks 11th on MLBs all-time saves list (358).

Name: Spencer Strider
Description: A 35th-round pick out of high school by the Indians in 2017, Strider blew out his elbow a month before the 2019 season and missed his entire sophomore season following Tommy John surgery. He returned to pitch 12 innings this spring, which was long enough to show that he had regained his arm speed and a fastball that can reach 95 mph. His curveball and changeup showed some promise but also some inconsistency, and he displayed better control (albeit in a small sample size) than he did as a freshman.

Name: Tanner Allen
Description: A 36th-round pick by the Cubs as an Alabama high schooler in 2017 and a 34th-rounder by the Rockies as a sophomore-eligible last year, Allen got only 25 at-bats this spring before having surgery to repair a broken hamate in his left hand. He's a solid hitter from the left side of the plate and controls the strike zone well, though he might not have more than gap power. He has fringy speed and arm strength and has started games on all four infield and outfield corners for Mississippi State.

Name: Ethan Smith
Description: A middle reliever on Vanderbilt's 2019 College World Series championship team, Smith posted a 1.58 ERA as a midweek starter this spring. His main pitches are an 89-93 mph two-seam fastball with heavy sink and a mid-80s cutter/slider, and he has run his four-seamer up to 97 in shorter stints. There is effort in his delivery and he battles his control, so he may wind up back in the bullpen in the long run. It's unclear how signable he'll be as a 21-year-old sophomore with three years of college eligibility remaining.

Name: Gavin Casas
Description: Gavin, a Vanderbilt commit, is the younger brother of Triston, a Red Sox prospect. Triston was the No. 26 overall pick in 2018 and hit 20 homers in his first full Minor League season.

Name: Peyton Glavine
Description: As a left-handed pitcher, Peyton has a pretty good role model in his dad, Tom, a 10-time All-Star and two-time National League Cy Young Award winner who won 305 Major League games and cruised into the Hall of Fame on the first ballot in 2014. Peyton, a 37th-round pick by the Angels in 2017, has pitched sparingly thus far in his collegiate career with the Tigers.

Name: Conor Davis
Description: Conor -- who led Auburn in hitting in 2019 as a junior -- is the grandson of Ted Davis, who was an NFL linebacker with the Colts, Saints and Dolphins from 1964-70.

Name: Ryan Berardino
Description: Ryan is the grandson of Dwight Evans, who played most of his career with the Red Sox and won eight Gold Glove Awards in right field while hitting 385 home runs.

Name: Dante Baldelli
Description: Dante is the younger brother of Rocco, the current manager of the Twins. Dante, who's 16 years younger than Rocco, hit .255 in 15 games for Boston College this season.

Name: Kalae Harrison
Description: The younger brother of Brewers prospect KJ Harrison, Kalae has the chance to be an up-the-middle player at the next level. He has a solid feel to hit from the left side of the plate, though theres not much power to speak of at this point. A fringy runner, Harrison does have good actions defensively and most think he can stick at shortstop, though some feel the lack of speed might mean a move to second base. Teams interested will have a commitment to Texas A&M to contend with.

Name: Levi Thomas
Description: Undrafted as a sophomore-eligible in 2019, Thomas helped his cause this spring by logging a 0.39 ERA with a 42/6 K/BB ratio in 23 innings over four starts, including a gem in which he blanked No. 1 Florida for six innings. He features high spin rates on his four-seam fastball, getting swings and misses up in the strike zone with his 88-94 mph heater and generating good depth on his breaker. There's deception in his slingy delivery but it doesn't prevent him from throwing strikes.

Name: Dylan Neuse
Description: While his older brother Sheldon (who made his big league debut last summer with the Athletics) is a corner infielder known best for his power, Dylan is an up-the-middle player who stands out with his plus speed. He stole more bases without being caught (12) than any player in NCAA Division I this spring. A right-handed hitter with modest pop, he struggled in the Cape Cod League last summer and needs to make more consistent contact and focus on getting on base. He's a solid center fielder with a playable arm, and a pro club might try him at second base after he played there on the Cape.

Name: Casey Dykstra
Description: Two of Caseys cousins, Cutter (second round, 2008) and Luke (seventh round, 14), were drafted and played professionally, although neither reached the Majors. The most famous Dykstra is Caseys uncle Lenny, a three-time All-Star center fielder and 1986 World Series champion with the Mets.

Name: Will Treuel
Description: Will is the son of Ralph Treuel, who played for the Tigers organization over nine years. Ralph has been a pitching coach for the Tigers, Red Sox and various Minor League teams.

Name: Dante Girardi
Description: Dante, a Florida International commit, is following in the footsteps of his father, Joe, who carved out a long career as a catcher with the Cubs, Rockies, Yankees and Cardinals that included an All-Star selection in 2000.

Name: Homer Bush Jr.
Description: Homer is committed to play at Grand Canyon University. His dad, a second baseman with the same name, hit .380 in limited action as a rookie with the 1998 Yankees, winning a World Series title.

Name: Jeffrey Hakanson
Description: A reliever for three years at Central Florida, Hakanson was putting up video game numbers before the 2020 season ended, with a 20/1 K/BB ratio, only one hit allowed and six saves in 8 1/3 innings. He comes at hitters with a lot of deception, hiding the ball well and using a slightly lower arm angle. Hes up to 96 mph with his fastball, and his slider has progressed over his time at UCF.

Name: Jeremy Wu-Yelland
Description: A product of the Pacific Northwest, Wu-Yelland has been a part of Hawaiis bullpen since setting foot on campus as a freshman. While he did get some time as a starter as a sophomore, the southpaw likely profiles best as a reliever because of command issues. After a solid Cape Cod League showing last summer, Wu-Yelland was off to a good start to his 2020 season (0.69 ERA, 11.1 K/9 and a comparatively low 3.5 BB.9), using a fastball that touches the mid-90s, a breaking ball and a solid changeup.

Name: Dominic Hamel
Description: A team that places emphasis on pitching metrics could select Hamel in the first five rounds because he has high spin rates on three of his offerings: a low-90s fastball that tops out at 96 mph, a low-80s slider and a mid-70s curveball with more depth than power. A transfer from Yavapai (Ariz.) JC, he one-hit North Carolina for seven innings but had a 7.11 ERA in his other three starts, leaving a mixed impression on scouts. They don't love his arm action or crossfire delivery, though it does provide some deception.

Name: Zach Pettway
Description: A three-year member of UCLAs rotation, the right-hander took over as the Bruins Friday night starter as a sophomore and had gotten off to a ridiculous start to his 2020 season with a 29/1 K/BB ratio. Pettway is more about his feel for pitching than pure stuff, with a fastball that will average 90 mph, a decent breaking ball and a changeup that serves as his best offering. He offers deception and an ability to command all of his pitches, giving him the chance to start at the next level.

Name: Tanner Murray
Description: A three-year starter at UC-Davis, Murray has built a reputation for making a ton of contact with excellent plate discipline and terrific hand-eye coordination. Hes displayed very little power because of a lack of premium bat speed and leverage in his swing, leading some to worry about how much hell impact the baseball at the next level, though his home college park has a reputation for being pitching-friendly. Some scouts feel he has the chance to be a very good shortstop defensively, and hes also shown the ability to slide over and play third, though that would put more pressure on his bat.

Name: Tim Tawa
Description: A two-sport high school star who was Oregons Gatorade Player of the Year in football for three years and baseball for one in high school, Tawa was a starter from the get-go as a freshman at Stanford. He wasnt able to back up his freshman year as a sophomore when he dealt with injuries and initially lost the shortstop job this spring. Tawa likes to jump on fastballs and has some pull-side power, though he struggled to identify breaking stuff. His versatility defensively is a plus, as he can play pretty much anywhere on the field as an average runner with an average arm.

Name: Hunter Parks
Description: A two-way player in high school, Parks made some intriguing strides when he focused on pitching as a junior college freshman. He has a loose arm that now produces 90-95 mph fastballs and 78-82 mph sliders, and there's still projection remaining in his athletic 6-foot-3, 175-pound frame. He's also making progress with his changeup and control, though it's unclear if his 21 innings this spring were enough to convince teams to draft him way from returning to Florence-Darlington Tech for his sophomore season.

Name: Dane Acker
Description: Acker made Conference USA's 2018 all-freshman team at Rice, then went 10-0 with a 2.36 ERA as a sophomore on a loaded San Jacinto (Texas) JC staff in 2019, when he turned down the Diamondbacks as a 23rd-rounder. He provided one of the highlights of the shortened college season, no-hitting Louisiana State with 11 strikeouts, though he got hit hard in two of his three other outings. He throws strikes with four generally average pitches, the best of which are a low-90s sinker and a slider/cutter.

Name: Daniel Federman
Description: Almost exclusively a reliever over the course of his career at Miami, Federman has been the Hurricanes closer the past two seasons and was off to a very good start before the shutdown. There are teams that believe he can start thanks to a legitimate four-pitch mix, though he struggled in that role last summer in the Cape Cod League. Hell throw his fastball in the 90-94 range and complements it well with his slider and changeup. He also mixes in an effective curve. He throws strikes and is willing to take the ball in any role.

Name: Mat Olsen
Description: An undersized right-hander with arm strength, Olsens name started popping up early this spring with a spike in velocity. He was up to 94-95 mph with his heater early on, but didnt have a chance to show if he could maintain it throughout his entire junior college season because of the pandemic. The University of Arizona commit complements his fastball with a hard low-80s slider and had struck out more than 15 per nine innings over seven starts this spring. With a high-effort delivery, Olsen might be headed for a bullpen long-term, where his competitiveness would be a plus.

Name: Braden Olthoff
Description: An unheralded transfer who went undrafted out of high school and during two years at Palomar (Calif.) JC, Olthoff recorded a 0.32 ERA in four starts this spring, ranking third in NCAA Division I in strikeouts (47) and sixth in WHIP (0.54). He struck out 16 against Cal State Fullerton, then worked the first six innings of a no-hitter against Middle Tennessee State in his next outing. He stands out more for his sink, command and deception than his pure stuff, usually operating at 88-92 mph and peaking at 94 mph with his fastball. His curveball, slider and changeup are generally average, though any of them can be his best pitch on a given day.

Name: Michael Brown
Description: Anyone interested in Brown, the NorCal high school standout, will be buying the bat. The 6-foot-5 first baseman has tremendous raw power from the left side of the plate. Long levers have led to some problems with velocity and pitches on the inner half of the plate, but he can drive the ball the other way and recognizes spin well. Hes slimmed down over the past year but is definitely limited to first base. Whether he can be signed away from his commitment to the University of Washington remains to be seen.

Name: Mario Zabala
Description: Based on raw tools, Zabala is the best prospect in Puerto Rico in this Draft class, but questions abound about him being able to use his tools performance-wise on a consistent basis at the next level. The Florida International recruit has tremendous raw power, but also displayed a ton of swing and miss against top competition. He runs well and has a strong arm, with a profile as an athletic power-hitting corner outfielder if it all clicks.

Name: Tanner Bibee
Description: Cal State Fullerton has a reputation for producing starting pitchers who know how to command the baseball and Bibee is no exception. He became a full-time starter as a sophomore, and though he pitched well in relief on the Cape last summer, he opened his junior year as Fullertons Friday night starter and threw well over four starts. He does it with average stuff across the board at best, with a fastball that can touch 92-93 mph at times, a solid slider and a decent changeup. It plays up because of his ability to command all three, though theres not a ton of margin for error and his ceiling is somewhat limited.

Name: Billy Cook
Description: Cooks parents were collegiate athletes at Air Force, his father a baseball player, his mother a basketball and volleyball player, and he brings that athleticism to his game. Hes played both the infield and outfield for Pepperdine for three years and teams that like him think his speed will allow him to stay in center field. He was taking a nice step forward in his offensive production this year, showing above-average power at times, though there is some swing and miss to his game. Scouts havent gotten as many looks at Cook as some other college performers because he came from the Colorado high school ranks and missed a chunk of his sophomore season with a torn labrum in his non-throwing shoulder.

Name: Zach Daniels
Description: Daniels has loud tools and helped his cause by batting .357/.478/.750 this spring, but scouts never got the chance to see how he'd fare against tougher pitching in Southeastern Conference play. His hitting ability remains a question because he batted a combined .176 with a 38 percent strikeout rate in his first two seasons and put up worse numbers in the Cape Cod League last summer. He's enticing because he offers well above-average raw power from the right side of the plate, plus speed, an average arm and a chance to play center field.

Name: Riley Tirotta
Description: Dayton has produced three big leaguers, including Jerry Blevins and Craig Stammen, but never has had a player selected in the first 10 rounds. Tirotta could have been the first Flyer to go that early, but that became less likely when the 2020 Draft was reduced to five rounds. He's an impressive athlete, a 6-foot-3, 210-pounder who can display double-plus speed, plus right-handed raw power and the arm strength and quickness to play a quality third base. There are major concerns about his bat, however, because he's a career .241 hitter at Dayton and batted .156 in the Cape Cod League last summer.

Name: Nander De Sedas
Description: De Sedas was a solid prep product from the same high school that produced Francisco Lindor, but an uneven spring in 2018 and a commitment to Florida State meant he didnt get taken until the 29th round that June, so he headed to Tallahassee knowing hed be a Draft-eligible sophomore in 2020. A switch-hitter who is a little bit better from the left side, with a little more power on the right, hes struggled to hit consistently in his year-plus at Florida State. He does show off solid defensive skills but is prone to mistakes, particularly on throws. That, along with his fringe-average speed, has some scouts thinking hes better suited for second base than shortstop at the next level.

Name: Cody Greenhill
Description: Greenhill has posted a 2.59 ERA with 19 saves in two-plus years at Auburn, and he didn't allow a run while logging a 17/1 K/BB ratio in 12 2/3 innings this spring. He can run his fastball up to 95 mph and back it up with an average slider that tunnels well with his heater, though he tends to operate closer to 90 mph when he pitches on the second of consecutive days. Scouts don't love his arm action but his mechanics provide deception and his 6-foot-4 frame helps create good angle on his pitches.

Name: Michael Guldberg
Description: Guldberg led the Atlantic Coast Conference in hitting (.450) while striking out just three times in 72 plate appearances during the shortened 2020 season, and he ranked second in the ACC batting race (.361) a year ago. He excels at putting the bat on the ball with a flat right-handed swing and he has solid speed, but he also presents a tough profile because his approach yields little power and his defensive home is uncertain. He injured his throwing shoulder as a freshman, spent almost all of his sophomore year at DH and played left field with a below-average arm this spring. It's possible that he could play center field and he did see some action at second base in 2018.

Name: Alex Freeland
Description: Hailing from the same high school that produced big league catcher Mike Zunino, Freeland made a name for himself with strong play over the summer. He stands out mostly because of his bat, with the ability to impact the baseball from both sides of the plate, with some power to come. Most scouts dont feel hell be able to stick at shortstop, his position at Mariner High School, but the Central Florida recruit could be a solid offensive-minded second baseman in the future.

Name: Mason Hickman
Description: Hickman's stuff hasnt stood out on Vanderbilt's loaded pitching staffs, but he has been a consistent winner who has gone 19-2 with a 3.13 ERA in three college seasons and earned the victory in the College World Series clincher last June. His best pitch is his solid curveball, and he also has an 88-91 mph fastball that misses bats because of his command and deception. He throws strikes and keeps hitters off balance by mixing in a slider and changeup, making him a high-floor guy who might become a back-of-the-rotation starter.

Name: Bailey Horn
Description: Horn missed the 2018 season at McLennan (Texas) CC following Tommy John surgery but has bounced back at Auburn to become one of the better redshirt juniors available in the 2020 Draft. His best weapon is a low-80s slider that shows flashes of becoming a plus offering. He also has a low-90s fastball that tops out at 94 mph, a get-me-over curveball and an effective changeup, showing enough pitches and the control to remain a starter.

Name: Matthew Dyer
Description: It hasnt been a direct path for Dyer, who began his college career in 2017 at Oregon, sat out in 2018 as he transferred to Arizona and then went undrafted in 2019. He was off to a slow start offensively before the season ended this spring, but there are some tools to like here. Dyer is a plus runner with an easily plus arm who shows above-average defensive skills behind the plate. Hes also athletic enough to play center field and second base, pointing to a potential future career as a super-utility type. While he has added a little strength to his long and lean frame, his offensive profile is somewhat limited.

Name: Wil Jensen
Description: Jensen was off to a very good start as a sophomore in 2018 until he needed Tommy John surgery. While he returned for only three appearances in 2019, the As took him in the 28th round last June, but returned to Pepperdine and was off to a very good start as the Waves Friday night starter. Theres some projection to his 6-foot-3 frame and he has a potential four-pitch mix, with a fastball up to 93 mph, a changeup that has the chance to be a plus pitch, and a distinct curve and slider, all of which hes shown the ability to command fairly well.

Name: Cullen Kafka
Description: Kafka worked mostly as a reliever as a freshman at Oregon then moved into the rotation as a sophomore and was the Ducks Friday night starter during the short-lived 2020 season. At 6-foot-4 and about 220 pounds, the right-hander certainly fits the mold as a workhorse type and he has a potential three-pitch mix with a fastball that touches 94 mph, a slider and a changeup. Command issues have held him back, however, leading some to think he might best be suited for a bullpen role.

Name: Niko Kavadas
Description: Kavadas is all about left-handed power and tied for the Atlantic Coast Conference lead with seven homers in 13 games this spring after tying for first in the Cape Cod League with nine longballs last summer. He scores very well in various hitting metrics, producing impressive launch angles and exit velocities while earning well above-average grades for his raw pop from some scouts. He's somewhat similar to Mike Adams with less hitting ability -- he has a career .280 average at Notre Dame -- and his lack of athleticism and arm strength may land him at DH.

Name: Chris Lanzilli
Description: Lanzilli slammed 16 homers as a sophomore-eligible at Wake Forest last season but fell to the Giants in the 39th round of the 2019 Draft because he wasn't particularly signable. He went deep six times through 18 games in 2020, though there still are some questions about how well his right-handed pop will play against wood bats and quality offspeed pitches at the next level. A fringy runner with solid arm strength, he has made strides with his corner-outfield defense but looked overmatched at third base when he played there this spring.

Name: Christian McGowan
Description: McGowan attracted attention when he opened the spring with double-digit strikeouts efforts in his first three starts, and he finished fourth in the national juco ranks with 58 whiffs in 35 1/3 innings. He works with a 90-96 mph fastball, has the makings of a solid low-80s slider and has some aptitude for throwing a changeup. He's athletic but needs to smooth out his delivery and control. He'll head to Kansas State if he doesn't sign this summer.

Name: Brandon Pfaadt
Description: NCAA Division-II Bellarmine's best prospect since Todd Wellmeyer (a fourth-round pick in 2000), Pfaadt made a name for himself by starring in the Northwoods and Cape Cod Leagues the last two summers. He can touch 95 mph with his heavy sinker and back it up with a solid breaking ball, throwing strikes with both pitches as well as his average changeup. He has a strong 6-foot-4 frame, but his stuff tends to drop off after a couple of innings so he profiles better as a reliever.

Name: Michael Kirian
Description: One of the better lefty relievers available, Kirian earned saves in all six of his appearances this spring, while allowing three baserunners and fanning 11 in 6 1/3 innings. He usually operates with a 90-93 mph fastball that reaches 95 and a solid slurve. He's not overpowering but his stuff plays up because of the deception in his delivery, and he uses his 6-foot-6 frame to create a difficult angle against left-handers.

Name: Mitchell Parker
Description: Parker turned down the Cubs as a 28th-rounder out of a New Mexico high school in 2018 and the Rays as a 27th-rounder as a freshman last year, and he'll likely get drafted for the third straight June after leading Division-I junior college pitchers in strikeouts (64) and strikeout rate (19.0 per nine innings). JUCO hitters have had difficulty catching up to his 90-94 mph fastball, which features deception and downhill plane, and his mid-70s overhand curveball. His long arm action and control leave something to be desired, so he projects more as a reliever than as a starter. If he doesn't sign this summer, he'll attend Kentucky in 2021.

Name: Michael Rothenberg
Description: Rothenberg has some of the best tools in this year's college catching crop, displaying solid raw power from both sides of the plate, plus arm strength and the hands to be a quality receiver. But there also are questions about his bat and defense, because he hit .200 with a 29 percent strikeout rate in the Cape Cod League last summer and he lacks consistency behind the plate. He performed well (.349/.551/.605) in the shortened college season and may have enough pop to make it at first base if he can't stick at catcher.

Name: Jake DeLeo
Description: Scouts didnt get the chance to follow up on this talented Connecticut high school standout this spring after he showed off some tools on the summer showcase circuit. Deleo is already fairly physically mature, without much projection left in his 6-foot-2 frame, but theres plenty of current strength and raw power for the right-handed hitter to tap into, especially if he can refine his overall approach. Deleo, committed to Georgia Tech, has caught and played the outfield and has shown enough speed and athleticism to roam the outfield at the next level.

Name: Gabe Shepard
Description: Shepard had Tommy John surgery as a high school senior in 2018, then came on strong at the end of his freshman season, working 7 1/3 innings of a combined no-hitter against Rice in the Conference USA tournament and popping 97 mph in the NCAA regional playoffs. Draft-eligible as a sophomore because he's 21 years old, he usually pitches with a 91-95 mph fastball and flashes a plus slider. He's 5-foot-10 and throws with effort, so there are starter versus reliever questions, and he doesn't come with much track record after pitching just 42 innings in two years at Southern Miss.

Name: Noah Skirrow
Description: Skirrow has taken a nice step forward, starting with a strong performance last summer in the Cape Cod League. In the past, Skirrow was known mostly for his 90-93 mph fastball with ordinary secondary stuff. But hes added a cutter, thrown 88-90 mph, that should be at least average in the future. It has some depth to it, and he was getting left-handed hitters to swing over it. He does have an average changeup and a below average breaking ball, so a team could send him out as a starter, but he might be suited best for a relief role where his fastball-cutter combination would play up a bit.

Name: Gavin Stone
Description: Stone made a successful transition from closer in 2019 to starter this spring, throwing a 13-strikeout no-hitter against Southeastern Louisiana in his final outing of the abbreviated season. At 6-foot-1 and 175 pounds, he's smaller than desired for a starter, but he throws strikes with three pitches: a 90-92 mph fastball that peaks at 94, a hard slider and a changeup. In shorter stints in the past, he has run his heater up to 96.

Name: Devonte Brown
Description: Swing-and-miss issues prevented Brown from claiming more than a bench role in his first two seasons at North Carolina State, but he batted .338/.429/.692 with five homers in 17 games this spring (albeit with a 23 percent strikeout rate). His bat speed and strength give him plus raw power from the right side of the plate. An average to solid runner with a strong arm, he gets mixed reviews for his play at third base and may wind up in right field after playing both positions this spring.

Name: Brendan Beck
Description: Teams interested in Beck, the younger brother of current Giants prospect Tristan Beck, will be ones that like college performers. The right-hander has been a member of Stanfords rotation since his freshman year and has had success with a four-pitch mix and excellent command. His fastball is average, at best, with a lack of deception and just fair life to it. Beck's above-average slider is his best secondary pitch and he mixes in an average changeup and fringy curve effectively. Some scouts see some ceiling as a starter because, as a player who entered Stanford as a two-way guy, hes still relatively new to focusing on pitching.

Name: Hayes Heinecke
Description: The 2019 Southern Conference Freshman of the Year after leading the league in wins and going 10-2 with a 2.65 ERA, Heinecke was even sharper in four starts as a Draft-eligible sophomore this spring. More strong than tall at 5-foot-11 and 200 pounds, he provides strikes with three pitches and owns a 120/18 K/BB ratio in 114 college innings. His best pitch is his changeup, which he sets up with an 88-92 mph fastball and a decent curveball.

Name: Darren Baker
Description: The son of Dusty Baker, Darren is best known as being the bat boy whisked away to safety by J.T. Snow in the 2002 World Series. After three years as a starter at Cal, including a strong performance on the Cape last summer, hes looking to show people hes more than a piece of trivia. He can really hit, with an advanced approach, using all fields. A plus runner without much power, he profiles best as a leadoff type. Hes gotten better defensively on the infield, giving him a chance to stick at second, but some think hell best be suited for center field long-term, with his plus makeup giving him the chance to maximize his tools.

Name: Jared Viertel
Description: The coronavirus shutdown severely impacted Viertel's Draft chances because he was building momentum and beginning to attract scouts when the junior college season ended in mid-March. His stuff took a step forward from the fall, with the projectable 6-foot-3 right-hander displaying a 90-94 mph fastball with riding action, flashes of a plus curveball and feel for a changeup this spring. His command and control are more works in progress. If he doesn't sign this summer, he'll pitch at Missouri State next spring.

Name: Kaden Polcovich
Description: The son of former big leaguer Kevin Polcovich, Kaden is a similar player whose grinder mentality helps him get the most out of his fringy-to-average tools. After spending the first semester of his college career at Kentucky and playing his first two seasons at Northwest Florida State JC, he batted .344/.494/.578 with 19 walks and eight steals in 18 games for Oklahoma State this spring. The stocky 5-foot-8 switch-hitter performed well in the Cape Cod League last summer as well, though he profiles more as utilityman than as a regular.

Name: Calvin Ziegler
Description: The top two Canadian talents in this years Draft class are both outfielders, but theres no question Ziegler is the best arm. While hes just six-foot, hes very athletic on the mound (hes a solid outfielder as well), allowing him to make adjustments and maintain his delivery. His fastball typically sits 91-92 mph, but he can reach back for more occasionally. He has the makings of a plus curve and he has some feel for a changeup, where his athleticism should come into play and allow him to have a solid three-pitch mix. The UConn commit will need to keep refining his command and not trying to do too much so he can stay within his delivery more consistently.

Name: Marquis Grissom Jr.
Description: Grissom Jr., who is signed to play at Georgia Tech, excels most on the mound. But his dad, Marquis, had great success as a fleet-footed outfielder, stealing 429 bases, slugging 227 homers and winning four Gold Glove Awards. A World Series champion with the 1995 Braves, he batted .317 in 52 career postseason games.

Name: Logan Steenstra
Description: Logan is the son of Kennie Steenstra, who made four Major League appearances and is the current pitching coach for Triple-A Norfolk (Orioles).

Name: Joe Baran
Description: Joe, whose dad is Joe Maddon's first cousin, was drafted in 2018 by the Brewers (22nd round), but he continued his college career at East Stroudsburg, where he enjoyed a dominant-but-abbreviated senior season as a reliever (11 innings, one run, 21 strikeouts).

Name: Orlando Hernandez
Description: Orlando, the son of El Duque, is a right-handed hurler, just like his father. The elder Hernandez carved out a lengthy career in the Majors and started more than 200 MLB games. Orlando is committed to Florida International.

Name: Tyler Wilson
Description: Tyler is the son of Steve Wilson, who appeared as a pitcher in 205 games over six MLB seasons with the Rangers, Cubs and Dodgers.

Name: J.C. Correa
Description: The Astros drafted J.C., the younger brother of their star shortstop Carlos, in the 33rd round in 2018 and the 38th round in 19, though he opted to return to Lamar each time.
